He said: Mr. Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to rise this morning to lead off Private Members' Business hour. We are here to discuss Bill C-301, an act to amend the Financial Administration Act. It is a bill that I thought would never see the light of day, just like many other very worth-while private members' bills that have great merit but did not get the luck of the draw.
I am very proud of this bill. I am in this House as an elected member of Parliament to duly represent the great people of Kent. It is their views, opinions, ideas and concerns that Bill C-301 expresses as legislation. This bill is in direct response to the concerns of my constituents. That is my job. I listen to the grassroots, and this bill is a concrete example.
A consistent theme in most every piece of correspondence I get is that people are tired of government spending that gives no thought whatsoever to the average taxpayer. They are fed up with paying taxes, while the deficit goes up and the debt soars. These letters from my riding are not from one certain income group, job category or particular area of the riding.
The notion of big government not managing our money properly is coming from farmers, factory workers,
students, housewives, small business owners, teachers and the list goes on. I hear it in my riding and I hear it from other members of Parliament on both sides of the House. This bill will go a long way toward restoring accountability to federal programs. It is what the people of Kent are telling me. I believe it is what the Canadian people want. On top of that, it is what the Auditor General suggested last week after issuing his annual report to Parliament.
If we ensure a strict monitoring of funds spent by federal departments it will help recover and regain some of the lost respect for this institution of Parliament and for individuals members of Parliament. Therefore, it is in that light that I present this bill here today.
I believe I am merely reflecting the views of average Canadians who are dismayed and disheartened with lack of accounting for how taxpayer dollars are spent. I will not necessarily get into a debate on the merits of the current government's handling of our finances. There are spending horror stories from every party, whoever governed this country.
This bill does not debate the past, but concentrates instead on the future to make every department fully and completely accountable to Parliament and thus to the Canadian people.
I have called Bill C-301 the common sense bill. It is a votable bill. While it may not be perfect, I hope the government side will look at it carefully before rejecting it out of hand. When .we think about it, the bill makes sense just about every way we look at it. It is what the taxpayers want and deserve.
How does the bill work? Quite simply. All government programs and expenditures would have to be costed out fully and completely before they are implemented. As well, any cost overruns would need special authorization. It requires long-term planning by cabinet ministers; they would be forced to present to Parliament a detailed report showing any program's cost and its effects on the economy, environment, employment and social programs to the extent that it is possible.

November 30, 1992
Private Members' Business
This would be done several months before any program is approved to ensure that taxpayers get value for their money. Furthermore, a minister would be required to report any spending above the budget estimate and the reasons for such overspending. All detailed financial statements to Parliament would be automatically referred to the Auditor General and the public accounts committee for close inspection. This would eliminate hiding the true costs, since we all have to pay taxes. Let us make sure the money is not wasted.
I believe that by forcing federal departments and projects to stay within their budgets or to be forced to deal with specific questions on their failure to do so, taxpayers will get more value for their money.
There is no question that if those spending the money know they are being watched closely and will have to answer questions concerning their actions, they will spend money more wisely. At the present time there is not that concern.
I know of a recent federal project which was budgeted at $30 million, and later came in at approximately $200 million. We need to know why there was such a cost overrun, but under the present accounting system it takes special effort.
If this bill had been in effect such checks would be done as a matter of course. There would be no need to go to great lengths to get the answers and no bureaucratic red tape hiding the facts. The bill would prevent the bureaucratic shell game. We would know exactly how much is being spent, barring any unforeseen circumstances like an emergency or something, with greater scrutiny of excess costs.
Currently I believe there is an inherent attitude in the federal system which encourages overspending and waste. Right now if a program was allocated $100 million, and by fiscal year end has actually cost only $80 million, the administrators of the program look for ways to spend the remainder so that the next year they will not have their allocation cut. We should be rewarding those people who bring in programs under budget effectively and efficiently. With no real check on how money is
spent, we are in fact telling them to spend every penny, needed or not, if they want more next year.
I will now get more specific with regard to this bill. It provides Parliament with better historical and long-term information on financial planning. Subsection 30(3) of the Financial Administration Act would be repealed and the following substituted therefor:
Every warrant issued under the section shall be published in the Canada Gazette within 30 days after it is issued, and a statement showing all warrants issued under the section, the amounts of those warrants, and a detailed statement of the purposes to which the payment was supplied and the reason for the urgency shall be laid by the President of the Treasury Board before the House of Commons within 15 days after the commencement of the next ensuing session of Parliament.
The only change from the current wording is the sentence on the detailed statement. The purpose of this amendment is to give Parliament more information on the special warrants passed.
The Financial Administration Act is further amended by adding, immediately after section 42 thereof, the following heading and sections:
Part 3 is "long-term planning". Section 42.1 involves the creation of a new program.
It states:
Where a new program is to be established requiring the expenditure of money from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, the minister responsible shall, prior to the commencement of the fiscal year in which the program is to be continued or established, lay before Parliament a statement showing:
The objectives of the program;
The estimated total cost of the program over its proposed life, and the method by which the cost has been estimated;
the estimated funds that will be required over the first five years;
the anticipated effects of the program on the economy, environment, employment, and social programs;
the appropriation out of which the programs will be funded.
A new section 42.2 deals with excess cost. If the minister is informed that the cost of a program will be more than planned, he or she may lay before Parliament a statement showing the amount and reasons for the excess cost for the year, and all the alternatives that were considered before concluding that the excess was unavoidable.
November 30, 1992

A new section 42.3 would deal with the Auditor General. Judging from his recommendations last week, I think he would be very pleased with this section. It states: "Every statement shall be automatically referred to the Auditor General who shall submit to the Standing Committee on Public Accounts a report on the statement and the program".
As well, a new section 42.4 would require that when a minister submits his spending estimates to Parliament for a fiscal year, information must be included on how much was spent the two previous years and how much he will expect to spend in the next four fiscal years. This would prevent government spending boondoggles like the green plan. Here was a project costing $3 billion but we do not know how much is being spent along the way. It is as if the Tories were saving up for an election.
Money for a project is announced, great publicity is generated but nothing gets done. A project should start at zero, needs are determined, and then come up with a figure.
I mentioned before about how this bill could help the Auditor General in his efforts as the watchdog of the Canadian taxpayer. He said in his news conference last week that it was time average Canadians got the straight goods on our financial problems and that public servants and politicians had better start delivering. I have been hearing that message from my riding and that is why this bill was presented for first reading on September 24, 1991.
After tabling his second report on government operations, Denis Desautels said he was pushing for truth in budgeting. I quote:
Too often Parliament is asked for spending approval in advance with no idea what the final tab will be. Things are done on a two-step basis: a little bit now, a little bit later. We want to get away from that.
I could not agree with him more. I believe Bill C-301 will make great strides in the direction that our non-partisan, independent, neutral Auditor General suggests. He has sharply criticized the Public Service and MPs for misleading Canadians about how their tax dollars are being spent. He said that the Canadian taxpayer is the victim of continuing bureaucratic waste and department sleight-of-hand, while serious cracks are developing in the essential services Canadians depend on.
I was very pleased to see that the Auditor General put his grievances into three categories: taxpayers' money
Private Members' Business
that has been wasted with no justification; taxpayers' money potentially at risk because controls are not in place to do a proper accounting; and, finally, money misspent through bad planning.
I have said time and again that the people of Kent in southwestern Ontario and indeed people all across Canada want to know that their hard earned tax dollars are being put to good use. Bill C-301 is a step in the right direction.
The Auditor General said last week that some departments continue to ignore the rules by not properly tendering government contracts. Industry, science and technology was raked over the coals for awarding $3.3 million in contracts without bids in competition. The prosperity initiative entered into 22 deals without competitive bids for contracts of up to $1 million. No statement was laid before Parliament showing how much money was needed and why. It takes the Auditor General to tell us in an annual report all these things.
We as parliamentarians and as watch-dogs of the public purse should be told these things here in Parliament before the Canadian people. By not doing so and by adding to the examples the Auditor General has given us only adds to the cynicism and mistrust Canadians have for all politicians in general. By working together, we can change all that.
The Auditor General stated: "There is a general widespread breakdown of management controls, including fundamental parliamentary controls. Canadians are very worried about the impact of the annual deficit and the accumulated national debt on their standard of living. We must tackle this issue head on".
In conclusion, playing the game properly and bringing in projects under budget in the private sector means good news and added profits. In government it means next year's budget is reduced. I believe that most Canadians would not object so strongly to carrying a heavy tax burden if they were convinced the money was being properly spent.
I hope everyone can see this bill as a breath of fresh air. I know that many MPs are so-called ordinary Canadians when they are elected to office, but something strange seems to happen when they get to Ottawa. They seem to forget about being ordinary Canadians and instead become politicians.

November 30, 1992
Private Members' Business
I had the opportunity of being a councillor and the head of a municipality for many years before entering federal politics. To many members of Parliament, this level of government is known as the minor leagues, but whether it is industry, sports or politics one must have a solid foundation on which to build.
As a leader of our municipality, we would strive for a balanced budget so the ratepayers knew where we stood. Our plans were done five years in advance and updated every year. Whether it is federal, provincial, regional, county or municipal government the money comes from just one source, you and I, the taxpayers.
This is what Bill C-301 is all about. At the beginning of the year our budget was addressed and we kept it throughout the year. Many members will say yes, but what happens in an emergency? The budget would fail. This does not have to be the case. You have to adjust, whether it is municipal or federal.
We had three emergencies during my tenure as head of the municipality of Dover township. There were three floods, two of which were very severe, causing millions of dollars in damage. Nearly one-third of the township was below lake level. We were spending nearly $500,000 a year on repairing interior dikes and drainage ditches which were filled with sediment after every flood.
To solve this problem, under the initiative of council we built the largest drainage pumping works in Canada to service the area at a cost of approximately $1 million. Now there are no repairs needed to the interior dikes for drainage ditches. This pumping scheme was originally slated to be built six years earlier when the ARDA dike was built around the township at a cost of $17 million to the federal, provincial and municipal levels. The upper tiers of government disallowed the pumping works because of the great cost. It was about $450,000 at that time. We were able to prove a saving of approximately $300,000-plus a year with it in place.
Bill C-301 is designed to plan projects properly so that this does not happen in the future to other areas of Canada. I could quote many other government projects in our area of southwestern Ontario where funding was wasted by the millions of dollars.
I urge all members to support this bill. A vote for Bill C-301 shows support for the average taxpayer. A vote in favour shows support for the independent and non-partisan Auditor General of Canada. A vote for this bill is a vote for common sense for a change. This bill is a result of listening. I want to thank my constituents for enabling me to represent some of their views by way of this private members' bill.

speakeroldname: Mr. Bill Kempling (Parliamentary Secretary to President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to take part in the debate on Bill C-301, proposed by the hon. member for Kent.
The bill seeks to amend the Financial Administration Act in three areas: special Governor General warrants, long-term planning and the tabling of public accounts. Each of these amendments seeks greater accountability of the government to this House. Each requires that the government provide further information in order for this House to deliberate where the taxpayers' money is being spent effectively.
At first glance, most hon. members from both sides of the House would be inclined to agree that adequate information and accountability are absolutely essential in the democratic government of the House to fully exercise its responsibilities. The intentions are worthy. The hon. member has given careful thought to the manner in which the Financial Administration Act might be amended to enable this House to keep closer watch on how money has been spent and how it will be spent in the future.
When we take a closer look at what the hon. member proposes, we will want to consider whether the proposed amendments are in the best interests of this House.
While this House might welcome new responsibilities and powers to oversee government spending, I do not think that we would want to invoke requirements that inhibit the ability of the government to govern effectively. Least of all, do we want to impose a regime that would inhibit the ability of the government to provide accurate and quality information to this House? These are issues that we must address in the amendments proposed by the hon. member for Kent.
November 30, 1992

In the case of special Governor General warrants, the amendments would require added information to be tabled in the House by the President of the Treasury Board and would change the time frame in which warrants can be issued.
I would remind the House that special Governor General warrants can be issued to provide the government with funds only when three conditions have been met. Those conditions are carefully spelled out in the Financial Administration Act.
First of all, Parliament must not be in session because it is dissolved, prorogued or adjourned. Second, there are payments to be made which are urgently required for the public good. Finally, there is no appropriation in which the payment may be charged.
The use of special Governor General warrants are restricted to situations in which all three of these conditions are met. The Financial Administration Act limits their use to these conditions in order to strike a balance.
On one hand, the government must not be left without recourse to funding when conditions spelled out in the act are in place; Parliament is not in session, the government urgently needs the funding or has no other means in raising available revenues. On the other hand, however, is the power invested in Parliament to vote supply. The rule that public expenditures require the authority of Parliament is the bedrock of our democracy. It means that government must call Parliament into session. It is similar in importance to the convention that the government cannot levy taxes without the authority of Parliament.
Some members of this House are concerned that irresponsible use of special warrants would detract from the ability of Parliament to hold the government to account. Special warrants have been used in different circumstances for over 100 years. The most recent examples involved the use of four warrants in 1989. This House will recall that prior to the 1988 election, the second session of the 33rd Parliament had met continuously for almost 24 months. Following the election, Parliament was convened for a mere three weeks in order to pass the free trade agreement legislation.
Parliament then recessed but not before the government had informed the House of the need for further supply in the 1988-89 fiscal year. It tabled supplementary estimates B on December 16, 1988. Later the House
Private Members' Business
adjourned and subsequently prorogued and the government requested the Governor General to approve special warrants. The President of the Treasury Board tabled documents pertaining to the warrants after Parliament reconvened in 1989.
The use of those special warrants was consistent with the nine other instances that special warrants were used since the Financial Administration Act was passed in 1951. The system has not been abused. The government has acted responsibly within the parameters of the Financial Administration Act.
The bill before us today of the hon. member for Kent would have the President of the Treasury Board report to Parliament 15 days after resumption. The president would explain the rationale behind the issuance of special warrants, including the purpose for the expenditures and why the matter was so urgent that Parliament could not be reconvened to settle the matter in a supply motion.
This House will recall that in the resumption of the first session in April 1989 two such statements on warrants were issued. In the winter of 1989 they were tabled by the President of the Treasury Board and prepared in the general format of supply or of supplementary estimates. They provided an explanation for the requirement of the additional appropriation. However, they did not address why the need for supply was considered urgent.
Under the Financial Administration Act the appropriate minister determines the urgency. The President of the Treasury Board can attest to this urgency in his report to the Governor in Council before a warrant is submitted to the Governor General. The president is not required to include information regarding the urgency of the warrants in his report to Parliament.
This House might consider whether such a statement might improve the ability of Parliament to monitor government expenditures. The amendment would place additional pressure on the government to justify the use of special warrants. We might ask ourselves whether additional measures are needed as outlined in Bill C-301, but I would emphasize that any decision to amend the Financial Administration Act should not restrict the government's ability to issue warrants under conditions now specified in the act.

November 30, 1992
Private Members' Business
The government will continue to require access to supply at times when Parliament is not in session, when there is an urgent need and when no other source of appropriation is available. That is where I believe this bill may go too far.
The hon. member for Kent wants us to redefine the period that Parliament is deemed to be not in session when it adjourns. The current period is 15 days. The member for Kent would like to see this extended to 90 days.
I can think of many instances where Parliament might adjourn for up to 90 days for reasons that would receive the full support of this House. The recent referendum campaign is a case in point. Under the amendments before us this House would have had to reconvene in the middle of the referendum debate had the government run out of funds. This would not have served the interest of the nation.
Hon. members from all parties worked hard in the referendum campaign. It was important to us to work in our constituencies to explain the provisions of the Charlottetown accord. There are times when our duty to our constituents and our country is better served through our presence in the ridings. These are times when the government will need to use special warrants in periods where Parliament is not in session for two or three months.
I believe it would be a mistake to give away the possibility of using special warrants at any time that Parliament is not in session. It would be preferable to retain the current provision so that the government would not be constrained under any eventuality by supply provisions.
The second issue covered by the hon. member's bill concerns long-term planning. The question at hand is whether the government has the responsibility to prepare strategic plans or whether the plans should be submitted to Parliament for approval. The hon. member for Kent proposes that when a new program is established the government table information concerning a number of long-term considerations. He wants the government to outline the long-term cost profile and
any changes to that profile. He also wants to give the Auditor General an opportunity to review and comment on the information.
This is a proposal that flies in the face of parliamentary tradition. It represents a significant shift in the balance between the government and Parliament. It would threaten the ability of governments to plan strategically. Worst of all, it could compromise the quality of information that governments now use to assess various longterm options.
The member's proposals means that specific decisions of the Treasury Board which are confidences of the Queen's Privy Council would be tabled in Parliament. The proposal requires that the Auditor General would rule on the validity of methods employed to estimate the cost of a program and to give an opinion on whether or not a proposal is reasonable.
The Auditor General serves this House very effectively by assessing whether value for money has been provided. I do not think that we should cloud this service by making the Auditor General a commentator before the fact on the government's long-term objectives. That is not a matter for accounting; it is a matter for political decision making.
The hon. member for Kent also proposes that a seven-year expenditure profile be provided for each vote in the estimates. This would be given information on two previous years, the estimate year and the four future years.

Mr. Speaker, it seems particularly suitable that this bill come before the House shortly after the Auditor General's report because its aim is to start a process to control better cabinet money spending opportunities.
Back a few years ago a committee of finance called the Cooper committee after its chairman gave an opening statement entitled "The Proposal for Improvement". It read:
November 30, 1992

The present budgetary process of developing and enacting tax and fiscal measures is inadequate. It fosters uncertainty, discourages efficiency, obstructs progress and hampers the proper functioning of government. It is time to get on with the job of bringing much needed improvement to the process.
The process of financial control of government is the concern of all Canadian citizens. As a member of this House who is a layman relative to finance, I share the concern and the responsibility the member for Kent shows and I share the responsibility to do something about it.
First, we as members have an obligation to the people of Canada in regard to the use of public funds. Second, we as members therefore have a responsibility to scrutinize how the money is spent. Third, we have a responsibility to do something about it if we believe that it is not spent well. The third responsibility is where the process breaks down. Bill C-301 is a modest attempt to start doing something about parliamentary control of cabinet power.
Our present structure does nothing about sharing cabinet authority with Parliament. At present Parliament is asked to sign the cheque but not to question cabinet authority to spend it as it pleases.
Successive Auditors General have made statements which are really variations of Macdonell's statement that government spending was out of control. They have all given many examples to prove that statement. The most telling proof I suppose is the continuing and growing deficit of this particular government.
We could spend a lot of time discussing the reasons for the deficit but it is obvious that this government, as did the previous one, is finding it impossible to keep the spending under control and is forced to settle in most years for trying to limit the rate of increase of the deficit. This obviously is not enough.
The reason we have a budget is to lay down the strategy for revenue and spending. The budget does not have a life of its own. The budget is part of a continuum which includes planning, which is legislation, budgeting, estimates, expenditures and public accounts. As part of that continuum the budget should be a management tool which is used to implement the planning which has manifested itself in the legislation which Parliament has passed in each case.
Private Members' Business
This bill suggests that the budget and estimates should be linked in the planning process so that Parliament will have some knowledge of what items are being suggested and how much they will cost. It attempts to make the planning and costing process automatic in its reporting to Parliament.
At present the estimates seem to have a life of their own with no particular relationship to the budget. Nor do they have any relation to public accounts. In fact I would challenge anyone to follow through the three processes-budget, estimates and public accounts-and explain to any logical, sane person what is the relationship of the numbers in the three programs.
To follow through on the continuum, estimates are in no way reflected in public accounts. There are reasons for this. Most of them are taken from successive reports of Auditors General. They are things like supplementary estimates which keep coming down at almost any off time, $1 votes, revolving funds, net voting which is not inconsistent with the requirements of the particular project, vote transfers, the envelope system, acts which define accounting procedures such as UI and pensions, formula spending and statutory votes, spending changes started without parliamentary authority, one recommendation made by the Auditor General in his last report, and budget changes brought about after estimates are passed.
These items show two things. They show a lack of the continuum and a lack of any responsibility between spending and parliamentary authority. All those points I mentioned above contribute the government's spending being out of control.
Government and Parliament need to take a global look at the financial operations. The present piecemeal approach is incongruous and contributes to the out of control spending. Besides attempting to force the government to look at the costs of its actions ahead of time, a lesson it should have learned back in 1982-83 when the research tax credit scandal was in place, and restricting spending by cabinet without parliamentary approval, we should suggest more restrictive actions than there are in this particular bill, restrictive actions such as no supplementary estimates, restrictive actions such as no $1 votes and restrictive actions such as having all increases to statutory votes require enabling legislation.

November 30, 1992
Private Members' Business
Back in November 1982 the hon. Ron Huntington, MP, and the hon. Claude-Andre Lachance, MP, jointly produced a paper entitled Accountability-Closing the Loop. I recommend this paper to all members of Parliament.
This bill should be supported. It is one small step in an attempt to control all phases of finance. It is an attempt for Parliament to see what is going on so that the loop can be closed and that every phase of every department and agency fits into the continuum somewhere and can be scrutinized for its adherence to the plan and the spending within that plan. It suggests that departmental estimates be subject to the paper, Closing the Loop, that departments be subject to committee's veto if they have not spent the money well in the past. Without such action we are bound to have further Auditors General tell us that spending is out of control. That is his polite way of telling us that we do not know what we are doing.
Without action we are doomed to more deficits and more puzzlement on the part of the people of Canada about whether or not the government really has any control over its finances.

speechtext:
This is a Private Member's bill, and since the mover is a member of the
opposition I think it is not unreasonable, after recognizing a member with a different view, to recognize the opposition again and then immediately afterward, a member on the government side. In these matters the Chair always tries to encourage a balanced debate, and I think that considering the time we have left, we will have a chance to hear a range of views on this question.
I will recognize the hon. member for Broadview- Greenwood and immediately afterward, the hon. member for Peterborough.

Mr. Speaker, through you to the government side of the House, when my time has expired government members obviously will have another opportunity to put their point of view forward.
I probably would have been a little bit more generous in giving up the time to the government had I thought that it was going to support the motion. In fact I was shocked when I listened to the member this morning, the hon. Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board, basically opposing the motion.
For the last eight years this government has been talking about this kind of accountability or control on reviewing and monitoring expenditures in trying to make sure that any waste or possible mistakes in the use of taxpayers' money are under a more rigid surveillance.
When my colleague, the member for Kent, approached me to speak on this bill, I said to him that I would not be surprised if there happened to be unanimous consent to pass this particular bill. As we were chatting about this this morning, I said: "This sounds to me like a motion that the government would put forward". Therefore, I was shocked. That is why I have to stick to my position here and support my colleague.
Speaking about him for a minute, the hon. member for Kent has been consistent on this point for the last four years, not only in this House but also in committee and in his community. I had the pleasure of working with him in his riding and speaking at one of his functions in Chatham just a couple of years ago. At that time he was talking about this kind of accountability in government. He has been consistent and unwaivering on this. This is the kind of thing the people of Canada want to see.
November 30, 1992

If the government had lived up to its campaign promises made in 1983 and 1984 before it came to power, that it was going to put the brakes on government expenditures and was going to streamline the government system, then perhaps there would be no need for a a bill like this. Government members said: "Listen, bring us to power and we will put control on government expenditure and we will look after the deficit and debt of this nation".
In 1984 when we left power there was a deficit of $180 billion. It must be remembered that half of that deficit was accumulated during the recession period of 1981 and 1982 and part of 1983. Is it not interesting that eight years later we are sitting with a debt that is probably close to $460 billion by now. I am not saying that it is not a difficult job to get a handle on the deficit and debt of this nation, but a creative idea has been put forward by someone on our side of the House.
The government is always challenging us to put forward new ideas and my colleague, the member for Kent, has pul forward a constructive and creative idea that would be normal practice in a business environment or in any household. When a price has been given for building a new porch, for redoing a roof or for a paint or plumbing job, a bill for twice or three times the budgeted amount cannot be handed in after the job is completed.
We have had situations in this system, in the bureaucracy of government, time and time again where the budgeted amount has gone right out the window. The final amount is sometimes six or seven times the original budgeted amount. To think that there is no process for accountability on that until sometimes one or two years later is wrong.
My colleague's bill is very constructive. Once again, when we challenge the government to act on its words, it walks away.
I want to refer to a specific clause in Bill C-301. The opening sentence of paragraph 42(l)(d) reads:
Where a new programme is to be established requiring the
expenditure of money appropriated from the Consolidated Revenue
Fund, the Minister who is to be responsible for the administration of
Private Members' Business
the programme shall, prior to the commencement of the fiscal year
in which the programme is to be continued or established, lay before
Parliament a statement showing:
I want to go to part (d):
(d) The anticipated effects of the programme on the economy,
environment, employment and social programmes in Canada.
My colleague has come up with something Canadians would really expect. Why would we not be satisfied in approving a motion that would justify taxpayers' money being used in relation to factors such as the environment, employment opportunities and social programs, especially in the area of employment?
If Canadians saw that government was adding additional funds to programs directly linked to helping people get back to work, all sides of this House would be receptive to approving something like that. We could justify that action to our constituents. What is difficult to understand is when these increases to budgets happen with no rationale and no clear explanation. That is when we get blind-sided by our constituents.
The hon. member for Kent has put forward a reasonable and logical bill. I cannot believe the government is walking away from a form of accountability that it has been talking about for many years. In fact, this is the kind of bill expected from a Conservative member. My colleague from Kent is showing some of his honest, conservative leanings. Obviously, this is a good thing. I support it.
I am totally disappointed that the government cannot in its thought process get behind it. The Minister of Finance stood in this House a few days ago and said: "We are waiting for it. We are looking for ideas from the opposition on how we can improve the efficiency of government and how we can make it a better system of accountability".
Bill C-301 is an opportunity put forward by the hon. member for Kent and the government walks away from it.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Science
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I really cannot do very much in one minute and 40 seconds, but I would like to use the time in the interest of all private members in the House on a point of order.
When I originally stood and my friend stood up and said that it was his turn and not mine, I understood the reason was that do we not usually go from side to side on a private member's bill. Then the Speaker stood up-if my memory serves me correctly and I would like to check the "blues"-and said that yes, it is the tradition to go from side to side during Private Members' Business.
I would just like to point out that is not what we did today. What we did is we started on that side with the Liberal member who presented the bill and that is perfectly in order. I am not questioning that. Then we moved over to our side to present another view. Then we moved back to that side for a view from the NDP and then we moved down to the other side for a view on an interjection by a Liberal member that it was really his turn and not mine.
I think there is a mistake there. I would like the opportunity to review the "blues". Then I would like the Speaker to perhaps have another look at the decision, which I believe was right, that we go from side to side on Private Members' Business. It is not three to one, three on one side and one on the other.
I think my time is up. If I am to fill another minute, the hon. member will never know whether I am for or against the bill. When he stood up his opening remark was that he assumed I was against it. I am in the government and I am a parliamentary secretary. I have not given my view that I was for or against it nor could I give and substantiate my view in the 33 seconds I have left.
I would appreciate it if the Speaker would again think about that three to one, three on one side and one on the other. Perhaps he could advise the House at this time if that is his understanding of the Standing Orders.

Mr. Speaker, I want the record to show that I was not debating your decision. I was seeking clarification before I spoke because had I sensed from the government side that there was any support for the bill I obviously would have taken a pass.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
Perhaps I may offer some additional clarification. Our parliamentary practice dictates that the Chair recognizes, in turn, the three main parties in this House on any motion that is presented in the House. Usually the government speaks first as the mover of the motion. Subsequently I recognize a spokesperson for the Official Opposition and a spokesperson for the New Democratic Party, and we then go back to the mover of the motion.
However, this is Private Members' Business, and the motion was presented by a member of the opposition. We recognized the three main parties, in turn, and it seemed reasonable to go back to the party of the member who moved the motion, especially since the motion will be debated on two more occasions and there will be plenty of time for members to express their views.
I think that in this kind of debate, whether there was sufficient opportunity for expressing all sides of the question, it should be assessed at the end of the three sittings during which the subject is debated. It sometimes happens that during the first session one side of the question receives more attention than the other, but I think we should judge the debate in its entirety. The Chair intends to see to it that there is a balanced expression of views during the debate in the House.

The time provided for the consideration of Private Members' Business has now expired. Pursuant to Standing Order 93 the order is dropped to the bottom of the list of the order of precedence on the Order Paper.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to speak today to Bill C-76, a responsibility of the Department of Finance, which contains amendments to the Canada Student Loans Program. It is a fact-and I do not think this is news to hon. members and our listeners-that raising the level of education of our young people means increasing their chances of having a better income and a better quality of life. I would also say that better educated youth means a better future for this country.
The Canada Student Loans Program goes back to 1964, and since then more than two million Canadians have benefited under the program. Since 1964 the federal government has guaranteed $7.6 billion in loans. We have some idea of how the system works: the Canadian government guarantees loans made to students by financial institutions for post-secondary education. The government pays the interest on the loan while the student is at university and for six months after the course is finished.
The provinces-we must remember that education is in provincial jurisdiction-have the right to withdraw from this federal program and receive full compensation. At this time Quebec and the Northwest Territories have withdrawn from the federal program and receive financial compensation.
As for the other provinces, they receive the students' requests and decide how much to lend them. The students have nine and a half years to repay the loan
Government Orders
when they complete their studies. Furthermore, they are entitled to an 18-month period after their studies in which they do not have to repay if they are unemployed for any reason.
We see that these are very attractive conditions and the problem which has been raised many times is that the federal and provincial governments, the financial institutions which lend the money and just about everyone are trying to help young people get a better education. We also see that the costs of those who do not repay are rising very rapidly.
In one of his reports the Auditor General said that the law was rather silent on the definition of "satisfactory academic performance", for example, because the assumption is that we will pay the interest and continue to cover the loan if the student's academic performance is satisfactory. That seems somewhat theoretical and left to the discretion of the student rather than the financial institution or the provincial or federal government.
It is probably a good idea-and this is what Bill C-76 sets out to do-to make three changes that will put the program on a financially sounder footing and at the same time help increase the amounts available for needy students. We must remember that the program is intended for students who would otherwise not be able to afford a post-secondary education.
The bill contains three changes which affect this program. It terminates the six-month post-graduation criterion. In other words, the student graduates, starts working and no longer has six months grace before starting to pay interest. I think everyone realizes the federal government and the provinces have substantial financial burdens, and if we endorse a loan and pay the interest on the loan to the financial institution for two, three or four years, and the borrower, in this case the student, has nine years to pay back, I think we can expect the student to start paying the interest as soon as he graduates, which means as soon as he has finished using the loan program.
We also want to have more clear-cut arrangements with the provinces that operate under the program and those that have opted out to ensure better co-ordination, better management of taxpayers' money, both

November 30, 1992
Government Orders
nationally and with respect to the assistance our students will receive under this program.
Finally, and I think I speak for the entire government, we would like to simplify the program's administration. At the same time there is perhaps a desire to review the way financial institutions manage this program. When a borrower defaults, they call the federal government and say: "Pay up". Perhaps the program could be streamlined to make the financial institutions a little more, I wouldn't say responsible but perhaps more involved in student loans, because it is easy for a financial institution when the provincial government says that Mr. X and Ms. Y is accepted as a student who is entitled to a loan. Mr. X or Ms. Y goes to a financial institution and arranges for a loan. The institution knows the loan is 100 per cent guaranteed by the federal government and the government will pay all the interest for the duration of the courses taken by Mr. X or Ms. Y.
For the financial institution the risk is minimal. If the former student does not pay the interest or the principal according to the terms and conditions for one reason or another when his or her studies are over, the government pays anyway.
There may be a way to simplify and update this program's approach without cutting funds and reducing a student's opportunity to get an education by establishing a better, sounder administrative framework.
In 1985 the program cost $286 million; in 1991, $453 million. It has almost doubled in five years. I think that it was right and fitting for the Minister of Finance to say in the budget and in Bill C-76 that is before us today that this program will be better managed in a way that does not penalize students.
This also means a better agreement on this program between the federal government and the provinces because educating students is the provincial governments' responsibility. The federal government is there only to help. We must help, but I think that we must do so at a reasonable cost.
This is the thinking behind Bill C-76 that has been tabled and I know that the Department of the Secretary of State has already started to work with the financial institutions and with the various stakeholders. A document on student loans is being discussed with the provinces and they are being consulted on it. Federal and provincial officials have been working together on a new approach and better administration of the system so that again taxpayers' money will be spent to the best advantage and young Canadians will receive higher education which they could not afford alone or even with their families' help.
I ask the House to pass Bill C-76 as soon as possible so that everything will be in place in accordance with the provisions of the budget speech and the Canadian government will save money at the same time as it helps our young Canadians get an education.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to speak on Bill C-76. I would like to focus on the subject of the Canada Student Loans Act in particular.
The reason I wish to speak on this particular segment is because of the importance of the student population to Canada as a whole and to the future of not only our country but the whole world.
At the time the Minister of Finance was introducing his budget, a very progressive initiative was announced by the federal government which was called "Learning Well Living Well". In it are a variety of interesting objectives and statistics which I would like to share with my colleagues and with the public at large.
One point struck me at the time. I was quite impressed by an objective of the "Learning Well Living Well" proposals. The major purpose of that particular paper was to deal with the ongoing problems in our educational system, with the productivity within our society and with a variety of other issues that deal with the question of education.
For example, I am not sure what happened to one objective at the time, whether it is still on the books or has been put on the shelf. A 10-year goal was spelled out which included cutting adult literacy rates in half, having 90 per cent of Canadians attain high school diplomas or the equivalent by the age of 25, quadrupling the amount of learning that employers provide to students through structured work experience as well as quadrupling the
November 30, 1992

Government Orders
amount of training employers provide to their regular employees, doubling community college standards and university post-graduates in science, engineering and technology, becoming a world leader in mathematics and science achievement at all levels of the school system, and finally having a system of life-long learning that would be among the world's best at setting standards of performance in accessing achievement.
One would ask why the government at the time was talking about those proposals. We on the opposition side know why there is need for some immediate action when it comes to the question of education and the question of literacy in Canada. At the present time on an annual basis we have in excess of 100,000 students who drop out before they finish high school. By doing so they are creating a growing number of functional illiterates who are largely untrainable and are increasingly an unemployable group of citizens.
Also in Canada now about 38 per cent of the Canadian population has difficulty reading or writing. That is cause for alarm. One would ask: "How can society move one step forward with these difficulties and these impediments?"
Even if we were to ignore those figures for a moment and look at what has happened in Canada from 1966 to the present, in 1966 about 25 per cent of the work force in Canada were youths. As we moved toward the 1970s and 1990s the percentage of youths in the work force began to shrink. By the year 2000, the percentage of youths in our work force will again decrease to approximately 17 per cent.
The number of students entering the work force is shrinking on a daily basis. One would say: "If that is the case something must be done". Even with these percentages approximately 30 per cent of youth are dropping out and not finishing their high school and 40 per cent of the population is functionally illiterate.
This is a very urgent matter and as we move toward the year 2000 the vast majority of jobs in Canada will demand at least 16 years of education. According to the 1990 statistics of Employment and Immigration Canada, 40 per cent of all new jobs in Canada will require more than 16 years of education. If we were to compare that with the jobs that require less than grade 12 education, about 35 per cent of the jobs would require less than grade 12 education.
In other words, unless one has a university degree by the year 2000 one's chances of finding a job in the labour force are going to be extremely slim. That is what I thought was the whole focus of "Learning Well Living Well" two years ago when the government came up with those initiatives, that something drastic had to be done.
We have seen very little in the budget to address not only the question of accessibility to post-secondary education but also the question of the quality of education we are providing to our students, as well as the kinds of accessory things the government is doing in order to make sure students are coming out of the educational system with the degree they need and are finding the jobs they require.
It is no surprise to me that the budget did not deal with that issue. In fact, if we look at the past four or five years, every time we had a federal budget one of the areas we saw being cut was that of transfer payments to the provinces for post-secondary education.
As such, if we were to look at the trend by the year 2004 there will be no transfer payments to the provinces from the federal government. To that extent one would only question the viability of the government proposal to address the question of education when in fact the federal government is cutting transfer payments to the provinces. By doing so it is minimizing the amount of flexibility that existed in the past in trying to pressure the provincial government to put more money toward education and to invest more in the area of education.
Student assistance in particular is a very urgent matter. As you know, Mr. Speaker, as a former student, as well as many of my colleagues in the House of Commons, many students who go to university to finish then-degrees live to a large extent below the poverty line, and we are talking about way below the poverty line.
I recall from my student days-and I am sure the student population who is watching the parliamentary channel will share this point-that students live on very little money during the year as well as while they are taking their courses. In many cases they are eating food that is not nutritional enough. Perhaps it is really affecting their health to a large extent. As it is, we are not really investing enough in education. I was quite surprised to see the provincial government was cutting the grant to the student population altogether when the provincial Government of Ontario, the NDP government, had promised to increase funding to the student population.

November 30,1992
Government Orders
I look at the federal government in this whole scene with all these alarming statistics and I think if this happened in any other G-7 country we probably would have seen an educational revolution of a very large proportion. However in Canada we seem to be content talking about it a little around budget time and talking about it whenever we have an opportunity to speak to a large group of people. In fact we are doing very little to deal with it and to address it in a tangible and effective way.
The government is not doing a lot in this area. In fact governments at the federal and provincial levels do not seem to consider it a priority. It is looking at it as a way to cut the deficit. It is looking at cutting assistance to students, cutting transfer payments to the universities and the post-secondary institutions and cutting the amount of money put into research and development. It is hoping to deal with the deficit but it is cutting off its own nose. There is no way we can deal with the question of the deficit unless we are investing in the most important sectors of our society: the educational sector and the research and development sector. Not only is the government not doing enough, the private sector does not seem to be doing a heck of a lot either.
According to information obtained in 1987, statistically only one-third of employers in the private sector have provided any kind of training to their employees when it came to education on the job. That is an extremely small percentage when it is compared with what is happening in Sweden, Japan and elsewhere.
One would wonder what is really going on in our society. We do not seem to be doing the things we should be doing to move forward and to continue providing the quality service we have provided our people over the years.
One would suggest that the federal government should try to address the fundamental problems we are faced with in terms of the educational system, in terms of research and development in industry and in terms of what the provinces are doing to address the problem.
I have seen nothing in the budget that addresses the question of transfer payments. In other words, in the past the federal government would give the money to the provinces hoping the provincial governments would use
that money to invest in education. What we have seen in the past is the provinces taking the money and spending it pretty well on anything but education.
There is nothing in the budget. I have seen nothing over the past four years being done by the government to address this particular subject. As well, I have not seen anything from the government side to try to address the objectives or the promises made to the Canadian population and to the House of Commons two years ago when we talked about dealing with the questions of literacy, drop-outs and so on.
I would like to see the government moving veiy quickly on a number of fronts. First, the government should deplore the action of the provincial government that is in the process of cutting grants to the student population. Second, the federal government should look at the promises it has made over the past two years. In fact over the last eight years we have been talking about the questions of education, literacy and research and development, and we have not seen a lot taking place. The federal government has to go back and look at those promises and bring forth something tangible now.
The government should reinstate the level of transfer payments to a level that is accessible and consistent with the needs of the student population. Somehow the federal government has to look at the whole notion of financing post-secondary education.
On a number of occasions student federations have put forward some very good proposals to the federal government addressing the question of post-secondary education, the question of accessibility and the question of assistance to students while they are finishing their education. We on the opposition side, my colleague and I, have been calling on the government on a regular basis to take tangible steps to deal with the question.
For the information of members of the House and the public, I would like to mention that over and over again institutions in the private sector, and in many cases some provinces, have been moving toward the notion of establishing a national education standard. A national education standard is the only way for us as a government, as a society and as a people to move forward with a healthy, productive society in a healthy, productive country.
November 30, 1992

Without a national education standard we will continue to have 12 different educational systems in 10 provinces and 2 territories, 12 different ways when it comes to dealing with assistance to our student population, 12 different ways of studying Canadian history, 12 different ways of dealing with the curriculum and 12 different ways of trying to deal with any question that might be facing the nation not only today but in the future. The government is equipped now more than ever before with the tools it needs to address this question and this deficiency.
A national education standard, as it was proposed by myself in 1991 in a private member's bill, Bill C-318, will help the government to address this issue. I would like to share some of the suggestions in this private members' bill.
For instance, the national standard for education stated that every person who is interested in obtaining an education would be able to obtain one regardless of his or her age, level of income or background.
It deals with the question of improved standards in mathematics and science. It addresses the question of apprenticeship programs and partnerships with the private sector in co-operative programs. It addresses the question of a national strategy to deal with the recruitment and training of the people who are in the work force, as well as those who are educating the students to be out in the work force.
The bill also addresses the question of work-load and the question of the curriculum as a whole. It calls more than anything for a partnership among all of the different levels of the government, the students, industry and the different partners such as families, special interest groups and so on.
These are some of the things the government should be doing and has not done at all in its budgets. Nor has the government addressed it in any way, with the exception of saying it wanted to deal with the question of fiscal responsibility and with cutting the deficit and this is how it can deal with it. However, we have a problem now and the government says it will deal with it at a later date. We have been waiting for that strategy for quite awhile.
Government Orders
Another issue the government has to look at is the question of summer employment for students. Since 1985 the federal government has been cutting the summer employment budget on a regular basis. In fact, in excess of 50 per cent of the total government budget for summer employment has been eliminated.
Other issues include the continuing cuts of $3.2 billion over the past five years from the federal transfer payments to the provinces. The government is taxing books and that should be eliminated.
On a final note, the government could look at the accessibility of post-secondary education to women, aboriginal students, students with disabilities and students of different backgrounds in particular.
I can see my time is running out. These are some of the reasons we have concerns with this budget as it was proposed by the minister.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jack Shields (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Employment and Immigration
subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today in Canada, indeed all around the world, governments are being asked to think in different terms. Just as Canadians are themselves thinking about their own budget planning in different terms, they are demanding that government adopt a new approach to fiscal planning.
Such demands to think and act differently are very strong when it comes to matters of money, particularly in times such as these. Canadians want their governments to be stewards of public money, of their money, and not spend as though from a bottomless purse. Canadians want stewardship because they know, as do hon. members of this House, that responsible, prudent, financial management of the public accounts is vital to the health of the economy of this country.
In 1984 our government's aim was and continues to be just that: prudent financial management and responsible stewardship of our financial resources. This government has been pursuing the goal of sound financial management through deficit reduction. This government is working to bring the public debt under control and is reducing inflation through its monetary policies and budgetary measures.
One such budgetary measure is before us today for consideration, Bill C-76. Bill C-76 will empower the government to use another tool with which to control the deficit. It will allow us to address head-on a matter that must be of concern to any reasonable government, indeed to any enterprise, be it private or public. The concern is the cost of doing business and of providing service to the public, or should I say recovering those costs. Cost recovery is fiscal policy that is practical and fair. It is an important tool for a government working to provide service to the public without adding to the deficit.
Three years ago we decided that the legitimate profession of lobbying should be made transparent to the public and therefore we asked lobbyists to register their activities with the government.
This bill is a priority of the government because it will allow it to recover costs now being shouldered by the taxpaying public for services that are very focused and very sector specific. I am speaking of course of the services provided by the Lobbyists Registration Branch of the Department of Consumer and Corporate Affairs.
While the beneficiary of such a specialized service is society as a whole, the cost of administering this service should be a cost of doing business as a lobbyist. I want to clear up any possible confusion that may exist about cost recovery as it pertains to lobbyists registration and the pending review of the Lobbyists Registration Act.
As hon. members will recall, when this House adopted the Lobbyists Registration Act three years ago we required that the act be reviewed after three years. What we are discussing here today, namely the recovery of costs for the registration of lobbyists, is on a completely separate track from the review of the Lobbyists Registration Act and it must be on a faster track.
Fiscal responsibility and cost recovery require prompt and separate attention. Accordingly my remarks today are focused on how best to contribute to achieving the government's economic goals as set out in the February budget and to fulfil the demands of Canadian taxpayers that their money be spent wisely and responsibly.
November 30, 1992

Bill C-76, which was introduced in this House in May, is one means of accomplishing that end. It will allow the government to establish a cost recovery structure and cost recovery levels under the Lobbyists Registration Act. Until now the cost of registration and the cost of the other services provided by the Department of Consumer and Corporate Affairs have been absorbed by the government. Given the government's priority to reducing the deficit, this clearly cannot be continued.
The Department of Consumer and Corporate Affairs is now considering the options for the structure and level of the fees. Until this system is devised I cannot say what the charges might be or how they will be applied. What I can say however is that public consultations will be an integral part of the development of the registration fee structure and level.
As you are aware, Mr. Speaker, second reading is to debate the principle of the proposed legislative amendments, the principle of cost recovery and fiscal responsibility. If the House approves, hon. members and invited witnesses will have ample opportunity to offer their input and advice before the legislative committee. I can assure this House that we will give serious consideration to suggestions made at that time. In addition, the proposed regulations will as required be pre-published in The Canada Gazette, providing all Canadians an opportunity to comment.
In conclusion, I would like to tell the House that the registration fees must not be viewed as an attempt to regulate the lobbying industry, which plays an important role in the democratic process in our country and in the way it is governed. The fees in this bill should be seen instead as a cost recovery measure, nothing more, and certainly nothing less.
Registration fees will become a cost of doing business like any other business, as is the business of lobbyists. More important, the Canadian government and the Canadian taxpayer will recover the cost of ensuring that those who attempt to influence its decisions do so in the full light of day. Registration fees are not regulation. They are not a hindrance to access to government. They are integral to responsible fiscal policy: cost recovery for the benefit of every Canadian.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is my pleasure on behalf of the New Democratic Party to open debate from our side on Bill C-76. For the benefit of the voters who are watching this debate, it is a bill which does four things. It increases the limits on business improvement loans under the Small Businesses Loans Act. It reduces the salaries of ministers of the government, including the Prime Minister. It requires that lobbyists pay a registration fee and, finally, the bill provides for certain changes in the Canada Student Loans Program.
It is on the latter that I intend to spend most of my time this morning. However, to call to the attention of the viewers what is involved and its significance, it should be pointed out that the Small Businesses Loans Act amendments would provide for an increase in the loan limits from $100,000 to $200,000, which is a change that my party certainly finds unobjectionable. The question really is whether it is of any great utility, considering the difficulties that small businesses have, even with the provisions of the Small Businesses Loans Act, in getting bank loans for the furtherance of their businesses.
This is an area of considerable concern. In fact the number of small businesses getting loans guaranteed by the federal government has decreased over the last few years as a result of the economic situation. Yet, the economic situation is somewhat dictated for a significant number of them by their inability to get loans.
Second, given what Canadians consider to be the proficiency of the ministers of the federal cabinet, for the benefit that has accrued to the populace from their activities, I do not think that this bill will be seen as enough. I think the average Canadian would prefer to see the salaries of the ministers cancelled. The only way in which one can do that is to have an election.
With respect to the registration fee for lobbyists, it makes good sense to us that services to which lobbyists have access be paid for. However, we have concerns, which have been expressed by others about the costs that might be imposed upon non-profit organizations for whom access to parliamentarians should be as free as possible. These are the people who are powerless and cannot afford to pay significant fees simply for the purpose of coming before Parliament or its committees. Talking to parliamentarians is difficult enough.

November 30, 1992
Government Orders
The significant issue in my mind is the portion of the bill that changes the Canada Student Loans Program. Part of it seems to be relatively trivial. It changes the conditions under which provinces that opt out of the federal student loans program will function. This does not seem to provide for any significant impact on the capacity of those provinces opting out to carry out the administration of this program.
The second part of the changes to the Canada Student Loans Program provides for the elimination of the presently existing six-month interest-free period that students have right after graduation. There was a six-month forgiveness period in advance of which the students did not have to start repaying their loans. This must be considered in the context of a number of changes which considered together are quite significant.
What is happening here must be viewed within the over-all context of what is now being said by just about everybody, which is that if Canada is to be successful in the global economy it must adapt to the nature of that economy. If there is one thing that is clear about the so-called new global economy it is the intense involvement and significance of knowledge in the new high value-added economies which are growing in the industrial world: in Europe, Japan and elsewhere. Any observer of the Canadian scene recognizes that if there is anything fundamental that Canada must do to compete in the new knowledge-intensive, global economy it is to provide that every citizen can attain the level of education, training and skills development that they can achieve.
It therefore follows relatively clearly that if we are to achieve this it must be by making it possible for everyone to have access to the kind of training or education which is most appropriate to their aspirations and aptitudes.
We should be talking about increasing training and retraining, and improving education at both the secondary and elementary levels, as well as the post-secondary level. The post-secondary level is very important to us. Our colleges and universities are of fundamental significance. They are a focus of a knowledge based economy.
We should be increasing the quality of post-secondary institutions and we should be looking for any way by which we can possibly increase accessibility to those institutions. However, what has happened? What has
happened even as this government utters the rhetoric that education and training are so important? With respect to post-secondary institutions the government has cut back the EPF payments to the provinces so that there will be a total of about $11 billion in cutbacks over a decade to the post-secondary institutions. Commensurate with that there has been a marginal increase in research funds.
Meanwhile, these transfers have had an effect on what the provinces do. In Ontario just last week there was a tragic decision by that government to eliminate grants to students, grants which make it possible for low income university and college students to gain access to universities. Grants are important to students with low incomes because for students who come from the lower socioeconomic strata of society the notion that they will have a huge debt when they exit from university or college is a considerable deterrent.
This series of decisions taken at the federal and provincial levels have led to changes which have made it more difficult rather than easier for students to gain access to universities.
With respect to the Canada Student Loans Program, just last year this government introduced a 3 per cent surcharge on the loans that students negotiate with banks. The ordinary voter out there should understand that the federal government guarantees loans to students which are negotiated with the banks and administered at the provincial level. All the qualifications are administered at that level.
Qualification by students for the loans is determined through their colleges or universities according to a set of criteria, one of which is that students must save 60 per cent of what they earned during the summer in order to qualify. There are also certain provisions for information on parental income and so on and the like. It has become more and more difficult for students to earn enough money just to keep themselves in food and clothing during the summer much less to contribute 60 per cent.
On top of these difficulties, this government is collecting $18 million from students who have negotiated a loan. A student who has borrowed $2,000 is going to have to pay out $60 right off the bat, and that is a hit. It is money out of the student's pocket. It is another deterrent to students, particularly to low income students who want to go to college.
November 30, 1992

With this bill the government will heap on top of that 3 per cent surcharge on loans an elimination of the six-month interest subsidy period during which it was understood that students were looking for jobs and would not be able during that period to begin immediate payment on that loan, in all probability.
The additional interest charges that will be taken from students will be $18 million a year. If it is true that education and training are so important to us and so important to our economy, even from the perspective of this government, then when will it stop doing things that are so negative in terms of those objectives?
There have been a number of recommendations to change the administration of the Canada Student Loans Program. The Canadian Federation of Students wants a movement toward tuition-free, grant-based access to post-secondary education.
My party would prefer to see a post-secondary educational environment in which students would not have to pay tuition. We know that economic circumstances at this present time make that almost impossible, but there are alternatives such as an income contingent student loan repayment program that could be looked at as a means of broadening access rather than restricting it as we are now.
Right now we have a situation in which practically every government, with the leadership and because of the actions of the federal government, is making it more and more difficult. How can that be consistent with building Canada into a nation that can, as the government would have us do, compete in the new global economy?
Mind you, the government did promise to eliminate the 3 per cent surcharge. If it is going to eliminate that 3 per cent surcharge why could it not at least have done that along with the elimination of the six-month grace period which is at issue in this bill?
We will oppose this element of the bill, as it should be opposed. We would ask that this government, rather than finding ways of taking more money out of the pockets of students, to find more ways of ensuring there will be more students, and that more students will have access to college, post-secondary education, training and retraining.
Government Orders
Indeed we should be looking at more and more ways to ensure that every Canadian has access to information, to the means by which we can learn. Why do we continually have this attack on those whom we are going to need most and who need us most, those who are trying by going to college or university to further their education and make themselves citizens who will contribute more to Canada than they could without their college or university education?
It is an abomination that this government continues to peck away at accessibility as it does with this bill. It certainly will peck away at accessibility. Students already accumulate an average loan debt per annum of $2,000. Many students will owe $15,000. With the promised increase in the limits on student loans students could be leaving university with $20,000 and $25,000 debts, which are going to be added to by the action of this government in Bill C-76.
This is unconscionable and unacceptable. I would say that this government, along with the provincial governments, should get together now to ensure that there are no more changes of the sort we have here, that there will be no more surcharges, no more actions to make student loans more difficult to get and more difficult to pay back and that there will be no more actions as there were in Ontario last week of eliminating grants that would allow poor students to get to post-secondary institutions.
We should not be looking at narrowing and restricting accessibility in terms of full or part-time as this government wants to do. We should ensure that even part-time people who want to go back to university and need the money to do so will be able to negotiate loans as well. What we need is a coherent program involving the federal and provincial governments to put a stop to this inconsistency and stupidity and engage in the co-operation necessary to ensure that universities are going to be properly funded and that students will have the financial means to get to university. We should make universities and colleges more accessible rather than less accessible. That is not going to be done by legislation of this sort. Therefore, we will oppose it and I hope all hon. members in this House will oppose it.

November 30,1992
