subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a few words on this legislation. I was noticing that no other member was seeking the floor.
The bill before the House is a bill that deals with student loans, the lobbyists in Canada and the Small Businesses Loans Act. The Canada Student Loans Act, in the changes made here in this legislation, certainly does not address the major problem of Canada student loans in that they do not give students enough money to live on. Students, in order to go to university today in Canada, must either have money coming from relatives or the family or they must be working because the Canada Student Loans Act does not cover all of their living expenses.
Some students make do and lose a lot of weight during the year. Some of them do without adequate accommodations adequate food and this sort of thing. It is very difficult for anybody-impossible for anybody-to exist.
We now have the Government of Canada coming along, changing the law and making it worse than before by charging fees. Then we come to the section that deals with the lobbyists in Canada. I do not know why this section has been brought in requiring a fee to be paid. What we should be requiring is more information concerning the activity of these lobbyists.
Then there are changes to the Small Businesses Loans Act and the Fisheries Improvement Loans Act. Here we are in Canada, with our fisheries in eastern Canada in disarray with substantial cutbacks in quotas, and the closing of fishing areas all along the east coast. There is a bill now before the House of Commons to change loans that are granted under the Small Businesses Loans Act through a bank and guaranteed by the Government of Canada and also loans that have been granted for fisheries improvements by the banks guaranteed by the Government of Canada.
What would you say would be the subject of an amendment brought today? Here we are coming up to Christmas with quotas just announced, substantial cuts all along the east coast of Canada, a moratorium on northern cod and fishermen are told they are not allowed to go fishing and are going to get $406 a week to sit at home. They have all of these bills to pay. They owe the Fisheries Improvement Loans Act of the Government of Canada substantial amounts of money on loans that they obtained for equipment in the form of nets, gear, boats, pick-up trucks and whatever, as long as it

November 30, 1992
Government Orders
applied to the fishing operation. What does the Government of Canada do today in this House of Commons? It has changed the sections of the Small Businesses Loans Act and changed it all to $200,000 for both of the loans.
The government has not done anything for the fisherman who is having his home or his property seized and sold under this Fisheries Improvement Loans Act because the Government of Canada refuses to honour its commitment to the bank. No, it is not doing anything about that.
When a third party attachment is put on the man's other income or an attachment is put on his property by the bank, because the Government of Canada says it is not going to fulfil a guarantee under the Fisheries Improvement Loans Act because it is out of money for this year, is the Government of Canada saying today: "We are going to forgive the interest on those loans or forgive the principal of those loans"? No, it is not. It is not doing that at all in this legislation.
The government makes sure that in two sections of the amendments to the Small Businesses Loans Act it points out with regard to the Fisheries Improvement Loans Act, with loans previously made to a borrower who is also getting a loan through the Small Businesses Loans Act, that the limit of those loans will be $200,000.
It is not the person who took out the loan under this section of the act who is at fault. It is not his fault that there are no fish in the ocean and he cannot make the payments. It is not his fault at all. Whose fault is it? It is the fault of the Government of Canada. Why is it the fault of the Government of Canada? It is the fault of the Government of Canada because it mismanaged the resource for which he was given a loan, the fishery.
It was the Government of Canada that gave licences year after year and even this year to allow foreign nations to fish the spawning grounds of everything that is in the Atlantic Ocean. Today, when I checked on the telephone, I discovered that there are 14 Japanese ships fishing inside our 200-mile zone with licences from the Government of Canada. That represents a 100 per cent increase in the numbers of their licences compared to last year.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)

I will tell the House what they are fishing for, since the hon. member asked. Right now on their licences it says: "Unlimited fishing of tuna", and then it specifies bigeye, yellowfin, and albacore.
The minister asked me what is on their licences. I am going to tell him. It gets down to the very valuable fish that is in the ocean. In fact, if we had one of them we could get $20,000 for one fish. Can you imagine getting $20,000 for a fish? Today we can. That fish is called the bluefin tuna. The average size off the Newfoundland and Nova Scotia coasts today is valued at $20,000.
The minister just asked what is in the licences and what they are fishing for. I am going to tell the House what they are fishing for. The 14 Japanese ships have as a by-catch in that licence 180 tonnes of bluefin tuna inside our 200-mile zone.
The minister just asked me: "What are they fishing for?" I am going to tell him what they are fishing for: five times the quota of Quebeckers, five times the quota of Newfoundlanders, five times the quota of Nova Scotians, five times the quota of New Brunswickers.
The minister asked me what they were fishing for. I am going to tell him. Five times the quota of Prince Edward Islanders.
We get 35 tonnes. It was the minister who asked this question and I am answering him. We get 35 tonnes in our quota. They get 180 tonnes this year. The Government of Japan was notified through External Affairs, through the Canadian embassy in Japan three weeks ago, in a diplomatic note: "You can have unlimited quotas". It says shark, swordfish, and incidental species to albacore, bigeye, yellowfin, skipjack and all these other different types of fish, unlimited quotas with no limit. Today there are 14 ships, 300 feet long, with helicopters on the front. Compare that.
November 30, 1992

Do you know what the largest ship in Canada is? The largest ship fishing today off the east coast of Canada is 170 feet long, with helicopters on the front, with unlimited quotas, with a by-catch of 180 tonnes; while Newfoundlanders have 35 tonnes and Nova Scotians have 35 tonnes.
How did that happen? I will tell the House how it happened.
The minister asked me the question so I am going to give him the answer as it relates to this bill, with regard to the Fisheries Improvement Loans Act in this legislation.
It happened because of a recent meeting called the International Tuna Commission, at which Canada sat down with representatives from Japan and the United States. They decided the quotas in the northwest Atlantic Ocean. The northwest Atlantic Ocean is off the Canadian coast. Oh, what negotiators we have representing Canada. Oh, boy, did they ever hang tough. They went in there and supported the U.S. proposal, which was 1,300 tonnes for the United States, 750 tonnes for Japan and 500 tonnes for Canada. That is for bluefin. That is not counting the unlimited species of all the other vessels.
This is at a time when our fishery is in serious trouble and when people cannot find the money to make the payments on their boats to satisfy the requirements of this bill under second reading and to be passed by this Parliament here today.
If the hon. minister wants to ask me any more questions, feel free to ask me anything.
The double standard in this Chamber and in the Parliament of Canada is glaring. The double standard I am referring to is that a student loan obtained by a student going to one of our universities, vocational schools or trade colleges is now subject to a fee under this legislation. There are substantial cuts everywhere.
Just compare that to this double standard. I received a letter Friday from the Minister of National Revenue in answer to a question I had asked. I wanted to know how many people, under this government, making in excess of $100,000 a year were getting the GST rebate? It is amazing. How do people get the GST rebate designed

for "low and modest income Canadians" if they are making $200,000 a year?
The minister answered in writing that there were 5,336 individuals with a total income exceeding $99,999 and 7,145 families with a total family income in excess of $99,999 who were entitled to receive the credit for this past year.
Just think of the double standard. Should somebody making $250,000 a year be getting something that was introduced by this Government of Canada, designed for and on the income tax form for modest and low income Canadians? The family allowance is to start on January 1. Should it be so designed by the Government of Canada that wealthy people can get the full benefit? No, it should not be. Not when it is cutting back on students, not when it is allowing drug prices to go sky high for our seniors, not when it is cutting back the provinces on health and education and not when it is forcing the hospitals to close beds. No. However, that is the double standard that has been recognized.
I wondered at what point in our history that programs designed for the low and modest income Canadians became payable to the wealthy in Canada. It is easy to find out because all income-tested programs in Canada are based on net income. In other words, you check to find out what is taken off your gross to arrive at your net on your income tax return and then you find out how these people are getting these payments and you discover certain changes have been made.
A change was made in 1988 in the Income Tax Act. A new line was put in. The line said exploration and development of mining, gas, and petroleum in foreign nations. For example, if people invest enough in Colombia or Myanmar, as Petro-Canada is doing, or in Vietnam in the Mekong Delta as a great many companies are doing, they can get their income down far enough to get the GST rebate.
Just think of the double standard between the rich and the poor and the double standard between people who are struggling to get an education as is pointed out under this bill, the Student Loans Act, and those people who are struggling to make an extra $250,000 a year and given preference by the Government of Canada.

November 30, 1992

This bill before us today rather than including changes that say that the Fisheries Improvement Loans Act will be matched up with the Small Businesses Loans Act in instances where the borrower has money obtained under both acts and that there will be a new $200,000 limit should do what the provincial governments of Canada have had to do. Under their loan acts relating to fisheries improvement they have forgiven all the interest. They have said: "Forget about it, we are in a very difficult situation in Canada so we will not go after you for the interest. We are going to forgive all this interest''.
The Government of Canada is responsible for the state of our fisheries today, for the terrible condition of our fisheries today, and it makes no such offer.
I would suggest that before this bill goes any further the government should introduce an amendment to forgive all fisheries improvement loans of fisherpersons who are found in areas in which there have been substantial cuts in quotas and all fisherpersons who have loans under that act in areas that are currently under a fishing moratorium.

That was the leaky budget, as I recall. He delivered his budget on TV the night before, but on April 27 he went through the formalities of reading his speech. I thought
Government Orders
it would be useful to quote from the speech because a lot of the things he said were so important.

"The sad reality of debt is that it feeds on itself. It places a nation on a treadmill. Mr. Speaker, today marks the beginning of a new era for businesses and individuals experiencing financial difficulties. Today the new Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act comes into force.
This is the first time in 43 years after six failed attempts between 1975 and 1984 that such important and crucial amendments have been made to the bankruptcy legislation.
These amendments will help Canadian businesses, big, medium and small, to be more competitive and to
preserve jobs. Businesses experiencing financial difficulties will have more time to reorganize, protect jobs and address financial problems.

2.7	per cent and, as he just said, it now stands in the third quarter at 1.4 per cent. The minister forecast a deficit of $27.5 billion and in the first six months of this year it has already past $19 billion.

The Canadian economy is weak because the world economy is weak. Because we are a country that trades with the world global interdependence is a fact of life, globalization is a fact of life. We have to trade with other countries.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, today is the 50th anniversary of the election of the Hon. Stanley Knowles to the House of Commons.
Hear, hear.

On November 30, 1942, 50 years ago today, a by-election was held in Winnipeg North Centre to replace the late J. S. Woodsworth, first leader and founder of CCF, who had died earlier that year. Mr. Woodsworth had represented Winnipeg North Centre since 1921 after his defence of working people thrust him into politics during the Winnipeg general strike of 1919.
His successor and the one he wanted to succeed him was the young Stanley Knowles, a United Church minister and CCF activist who had run twice before for Parliament in 1935 and in 1940. Stanley would carry on the tradition of Woodsworth, picking up his concern for rail workers in Winnipeg and the abrogation of their pension rights, particularly by the CPR, that went back to the 1919 strike. In 1948 he succeeded in getting those pension rights back and protecting further abuses of that kind by the railways against striking workers.
November 30. 1992

The son of a railway worker himself, Stanley's base of support was to be found at both CN's Transcona shops and CP's Weston shops. Election after election and in between elections for over four decades Stanley could be found standing at the shop gate handing out Hansard, handing out not propaganda, not what he was going to say, not a simplified version, but all of what he had to say and all of what he had repeatedly said on behalf of working Canadians, someone who took Canadians seriously and did not try to influence them with catch phrases tested by focus groups. Stanley was out there the day after the election, too, saying thank you, something that I did with him after his last election in February 1980.1 remember being there with Stanley in the cold of that particular month as the guys went in the shop gate and they said: "Congratulations, Mr. Knowles, way to go, kid. Look after him, Stanley, show him the ropes". And he did, as he showed so many other people the ropes in this place.
Stanley, you knew how to say thank you, but so many more Canadians owe a thank you to you for your persistence and precise use of the rules to advocate so many causes, like the end of the means test for old age security and the lowering of the pensionable age, two of your greatest accomplishments.
Stanley was and is a House of Commons person and it is a source of true joy to all of us who know him that unlike so many others he can have the real privilege today of celebrating his 50th anniversary and of being in the Chamber to do so, surely a unique achievement in Canadian parliamentary history.
Just the fact that Stanley continues to be present in this Chamber gives it a certain dignity. Canadians take comfort in knowing that you are here, Stanley. Time and again I am asked by people in Winnipeg about Stanley and how he is doing. Stanley, you occupy a special place in the hearts of many Winnipegers and indeed many Canadians.
As midwife to the birth of the NDP, as trusted adviser and House leader to M. J. Coldwell, Tommy Douglas, David Lewis and Ed Broadbent, as a friend to the hon. member for Yukon, as an early friend of women's issues,
Tributes
as an expert in parliamentary procedure and defender of Parliament during the 1956 pipeline debate, and at all other times, and more recently as an example to Canadians who have suffered a stroke, of perseverance and of devotion to the work of a lifetime, we salute you.
May God grant you many more years in this Chamber which you so ably served and in which you served the Canadian people in such an outstanding and selfless way.
Hear, hear.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to pay tribute to a truly great Canadian, one who has inspired parliamentarians both past and present and indeed all Canadians with his dedication to the work of this House and to this country.
It was 50 years ago today that Stanley Howard Knowles was first elected to the House of Commons to represent the riding of Winnipeg North Centre. He worked hard on behalf of his constituents and served them exceedingly well. To prove this point they re-elected him 12 times-12 times, Mr. Speaker-between 1942 and 1980.
From the moment Stanley Knowles set foot in this House he fought tirelessly to improve social justice for all Canadians. He outlined his goals in his maiden speech on February 3, 1943 and remained loyal to those principles throughout his long and distinguished parliamentary career.
One of his key achievements was to succeed in having pension benefits for senior citizens improved. As a matter of fact, when he first came to Ottawa pensions were only $20 a month.
Mr. Knowles has worn many hats over the years, often at the same time. A few of those included that of worker, trade unionist, minister, scholar, social activist, family man and of course parliamentarian.
We are honoured to still have Mr. Knowles among us today providing guidance, advice and inspiration. He is arguably the foremost expert on parliamentary rules and procedures in Canada today. As a fellow octogenarian, it is certainly a privilege for me to have the opportunity to pay this tribute to a great Canadian and long-time friend.

November 30, 1992
Tributes
Mr. Speaker-and you should pay attention to this; it is for you if you are listening or not-back in the seventies there was a controversial bill in the House of Commons to improve the pay of members of Parliament. Quite a sizeable increase was recommended. This may come as a shock to a lot of people, but I did not approve of it and I voted against it. There were other changes in it. There were increases for cabinet ministers.
One of the things that struck me was, with all due respect to cabinet, I felt there was one member in the House of Commons who was entitled to a reasonable increase and that was no other than the Speaker; it was Mr. Jerome at that time. I said the Speaker should be entitled to a cabinet minister's salaiy. I went over and talked to Stanley about it and he helped me word it. In any event it went through, but when it was over Stanley came over and said: "Stan, you are the only member of Parliament in the opposition who was ever able to get a money bill through" because that was an increase in salary.
Again, Stanley, it is a privilege and a pleasure to be here to invite all members of this House to join me in paying tribute to the Hon. Stanley Knowles, someone who makes us all proud to be part of Canada's parliamentary tradition.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to join in the congratulations to Mr. Knowles in celebration of his 50th anniversary. I bring greetings not only of the Liberal Party but as the member of Parliament representing the same seat as Mr. Knowles did. I always say to people I have both the great fortune and the great lack of fortune to have the former member of Parliament sitting in front of me at all times.
I can say at times when I stand here I can see Mr. Knowles sit upright as he turns to see whether or not I am representing Winnipeg North Centre in his tradition. Despite our partisan difference I hope he feels the people are being represented.
On a personal note, Mr. Knowles' reputation has lived on and on in Winnipeg North Centre. When I go to many places in the community-and I do not mean just among the seniors or the elderly but I mean among all age
groups-people ask me regularly: "How is Mr. Knowles, how is he doing, is he still in the House every day?"
It is real tribute to somebody who represents an area for as many years as he did that many years after people still inquire. Those of us who are now serving in the House aside from the Table understand just how difficult it is to be that well respected. It is a tribute to all of us that he continues to share with us every day what goes on in this House.
I know I will bring back to the people of Winnipeg North Centre his goodwill. They in turn will wish to hear from him that he continues to be interested in the House. On behalf of the Liberal caucus and the people of Winnipeg North Centre, I again say congratulations to you, sir, and it is fine to have you here.

Mr. Speaker, I too want to say a few words.
I remember when I first came here in 1968 that Stanley Knowles was then here about 26 years. I thought, boy, that is a long time to be a member of Parliament or to be associated with the House of Commons. Now it is 24 years later and he is celebrating the 50th anniversary of his election to the House of Commons in 1942.
Not only is November 30 the 50th anniversary of his election to the House, November 30 is the 13th anniversary of his appointment to the Queen's Privy Council on November 30, 1979. On both counts I want to congratulate the hon. Stanley Knowles, the former member for Winnipeg North Centre.
Back in 1942 when he was elected, he was elected with a majority of some 6,900 votes. His campaign manager in those days was David Lewis. Mr. Knowles has told me about that campaign when he succeeded J. S. Woods-worth. He told me about a fund raiser that was organized by the CCF in the old Marlborough Hotel in Winnipeg. It created a stir among CCF circles in Manitoba because he decided to charge $1.50 ticket for this fund raising dinner back in 1942. We can see how times have really changed since those days.
Not only was Stanley elected in 1942 but he was re-elected another 12 times. To be elected to the House of Commons 13 times is quite an honour for any person in this country.
November 30, 1992

Stanley was elected, as I said, 50 years ago and there is no one in this Chamber, either as a member of Parliament or working on our staffs, who was here at the time when Stanley Knowles first came to Ottawa. I guess you have outlived everybody Stanley. You have survived absolutely everyone.
One of my memories about Mr. Knowles was not only was he Mr. Parliament when I first came here in 1968, but shortly thereafter, in 1973 when he turned 65 years old, we had a celebration for him in the Speaker's room 16, just behind the Chamber. The Minister of National Health and Welfare of the Liberal government at that time presented Mr. Knowles with his very first pension cheque. He might be the only Canadian in history who actually had the Minister of National Health and Welfare come to him at a reception and present him with his very first old age pension cheque. I remember that like it was yesterday.
Mr. Knowles, we want to say to you from the bottom of our hearts: You have made this institution a much greater place. You made this country a much greater place, and there are an awful lot of us who owe an awful lot to you. We hope you are here with us for many years to come.

Third, many families do not have the privilege of having meaningful work in that there are about 1.6 million Canadians now unemployed.
When we examine that situation and some of the provisions contained in the budgetary papers of the Minister of Finance-one of them being a 3 per cent administration fee on student loans, and also the elimination of the six-month interest-free period for students who have graduated and cease to be a full-time student.
To the casual observer these measures may not provide all that much difficulty. I am here to speak on behalf of my constituents who believe that these measures are regressive and are not necessary. They do very little to facilitate students who are going into the work force and those who are not there at the present time, nor do they assist students who are presently having to seek financial aid to go on to post-secondary education of some sort.
In my constituency I have met with literally dozens upon dozens of students who have come up against a brick wall. There is no summer employment and family income has been taxed 32 times by this administration in the last number of years. The Government of Canada is presently using tables for the purposes of calculating the family contribution dating back to 1983-84. They are vastly outdated.
The other aspect is that, as I said, many families and many bread-winners are now finding themselves without any form of work whatsoever.
To tell students who wish to pursue their post-secondary education that they will have to pay off the top-note that it is off the top-a 3 per cent charge is rather tough.
I know that there are members in this chamber who have children, daughters and sons and some even grandsons and granddaughters who are going to university and they do not find that to be a very burdensome fact of life. When I go back and trace my own roots going into post-secondary education, my parents were janitors. I had to borrow the money to go to university, and a 3 per cent charge off the top is a lot of money.
To some oil baron or some major contractor or lawyer or doctor, whatever it may be, maybe that is not burdensome. It is the kind of money that you can buy your books with, 3 per cent. It is the kind of money that pays for the aeroplane ticket to one's home at Christmas. That is what it means.
I cannot for the life of me understand the government of the day when it talks about a prosperity agenda and turning around and slapping students with a 3 per cent off the top administrative fee.
The government's retort to my assertion is the following: "Students who have gone on to university and who have received money from the Government of Canada are not paying it back, and we have to take measures to ensure that we are going to get that money back".
I have suggested to the Secretary of State and other ministers of the Crown that there is a way this can be done. Many students who leave university-and one of the great examples is in the city of Toronto-cannot find work. MBAs and students with BAs in education and the sciences cannot find meaningful employment.
What does the government do? It is taxing students today at a 3 per cent administrative fee. What does it do to the students who do graduate?

November 30, 1992

If the Government of Canada finds itself in the precarious position on defaulted student loans in excess of $700 million, if that is the case, why does it not think? I would think that if you were in business and somebody owed you that kind of money you would look at the situation and you would say: "It is awful. We have to do something to recoup that money".
The first thing you have to do is send out notice to those students who have found meaningful work and have an ability to pay, that they should pay back. Nobody in this country who is reasonable would disagree with that. If the lawyers and the doctors are out there practising law and medicine and making money they should be paying the money back to the Government of Canada which loaned them the money to pursue their education.
What about the thousands and thousands of students who want to pay back the money they have borrowed but who cannot get a job? In my end of the country, in Cape Breton, many students have had to leave to go elsewhere to find employment, whether it be in British Columbia or in Alberta or in Toronto.
There are no jobs there. Those jobs are gone. What happens? This government says it is not going to give it to you interest-free for sue months; it is going to ding you right away. educated, more experienced, talented young people who will have some semblance of experience because, as we know and we all have it in our districts, students are caught. Why could the government not come up with some sort of a package? You are not going to get the $700 million by socking it to the students who do not have an ability to pay. Surely the Government of Canada has to be a little bit more imaginative. Maybe we can do something with the Canadian Federation of Independent Business.
Students are prepared to take the risk, to take the challenge, to take the opportunity to get the experience and to get their debt ratios down. I was very fortunate when I graduated from university. I was able to get a job and pay back the money I owed the Canada Student Loans Program, for which I am very thankful.
I have constituents who come to my riding office who are desperate, who have no form of employment, who cannot get an aeroplane ticket or a car to go to Toronto to get a job. As my friend will say, there are no jobs in Toronto. They have been terminated.
This thing about having a 3 per cent administrative fee on students today and then turning around and shortchanging them with regard to those who do graduate come August 1, 1993 to eliminate the six-month interest-free period is absolutely nonsense and does nothing to resolve the problem which is facing young people in this country.

Surely the stakeholders, the students and parents would want to have a meaningful dialogue on how we can address some of the deficiencies which are numerous in the Canada Student Loans Program.

The government has to be creative. It has to be creative with some players who are out there, for instance some of our national social agencies such as the Canadian Federation of Independent Businesses. November 30, 1992

1 graduated in commerce. If you have a student who does not have the ability to pay, perhaps that student can work for 12,14,16 or 18 months with the United Appeal. Make a contribution to the United Appeal. Maybe it is a marketing expert. Maybe it is a financial expert. You work to pay off your student loan. It is not written off at the taxpayers' expense. You have to make a contribution to the community, to those social agencies which are out there, in order to lessen the debt for students.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to recognize my colleague's good grasp of the situation. However, when he suggests that the government should become creative in attempting to collect this $700 million of outstanding debt, I am sure he is aware-I want to highlight it, I want to put it on the record-that the government has become very, very creative. It has in fact farmed out the collection of outstanding student loans to the sharks out there. I read where the various private collection agencies are vying for these very lucrative contracts to get their teeth into
these students, or failing that if the students have no jobs, get after their parents.
I am not exaggerating. These people are like sharks. They harass these people at school. They say: When are you going to pay, and the student says I have no job, I cannot pay.
I cite the case of a 53-year old constituent who came into my office and borrowed $4,000 about 15 years ago. He said that he made a pact with the government to pay $20 a month. But he said: "As I pay my token toward the debt, it is expanding faster than I can pay it". He asks: "who is going to hire a 53-year-old?" He is not employable, he accepts that fact which is really a tragic statement for an individual to make. The government is not prepared to give him a chance. In fact, it goes one step further and puts it out to these collection people who harass and harass. In the case of young people, if they cannot pay it, they say: "Well, can't the parents pay it? Take money out of their RRSPs".
Surely there must be a better way. It is creative but it is certainly not acceptable. It is not compassionate in any way. Granted there are dodgers out there who they have to be come down on hard, but for every dodger I am sure there are 25 or more good, sincere, ambitious young people who want to work.
I ask the member to comment on this policy that the government has initiated.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank my hon. colleague for raising this aspect about the harassment which is taking place of students who have left university and who are attempting to find work. He is quite right.
The harassment which is taking place is totally unacceptable to young people, to me as a legislator and hopefully to this House. Some of the tactics which are being used are just unbelievable. If one were to use the code word from the movies loan sharks that is what it looks like.
These individuals are being called at home, receiving letters in the mail, called at work, even if it is part-time work as baby-sitters. There are uncles being called, grandmothers being called, family members being called. There may be a separation in the home, a father has gone or a mother has gone. They are calling these individuals to try to get their pound of flesh.
November 30, 1992

That is totally unacceptable. It underlines, in my view, the need for us to be creative. Let us remember that when you get a Canada student loan the bank does not lose any interest. The bank gets paid because it is guaranteed by the federal government. Perhaps there is a way in which we can do something on the interest with regard to these loans which are outstanding.
In my constituency there is a young person who is paying interest at 17 per cent because that is what it was at the time. Interest rates were high. He was locked in at that time. Therefore that person has to pay the money back.
We have to be more imaginative, more creative. Since the money is paid to the bank and it is owed to the Government of Canada, I think we have to look at ways to revise the rate of interest which is being paid. As the member has correctly pointed out, a constituent who has agreed to pay x number of dollars finds out after five or six years it has not done anything really to the principal because it is all going to interest.
Those are the kinds of things that I think we as a Parliament must attempt to do for students in this country who are trying to pursue their post-secondary education.

subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to speak to this bill, Bill C-76. As you know, there are four aspects to this bill. It makes changes to the Canada Student Loans Program. It makes changes to lobbyists who are required to pay a registration fee. It is going to reduce salaries of ministers and it is going to increase limits for business improvement loans under the Small Businesses Loans Act. I would like to make comments about all of these, some in more detail than others.
Very briefly, with respect to the increase in registration fees or providing registration fees for lobbyists, there is nothing wrong with that except that the government does not seem to be distinguishing between lobby groups. There are a lot of lobby groups in this country that are doing a good job that are lobbying for the disadvantaged. These groups tend to be non-profit groups or groups with very little funding. They can ill afford to pay registration fees.
Lord knows we need groups lobbying for women, minorities, native peoples, the disabled, the homeless,
Government Orders
the poor, et cetera. There should be an exemption for those types of groups which are doing very good work, work that often is not done by this government, work that needs to be done in this country.
The next area I want to talk about briefly is with respect to ministers' salaries. We welcome the fact that salaries of ministers of the Crown will be reduced by approximately 2.5 per cent of their total income. That is a token amount and that is appreciated.
However, I would suggest a better approach would be the one suggested by my leader, the hon. member for Yukon, the Leader of the New Democratic Party who suggested that with regard to members of Parliament who have to pass any legislation that deals with members' income, members' pensions, perks, and the rest of it, it should pass by this House.
However, it is not appropriate for us to be doing this ourselves. As we have suggested, there should be a committee, an independent body set up that will make recommendations to this House with respect to MPs' salaries, ministers' salaries, perks, pensions, everything that surrounds a member of Parliament or minister of the Crown. That package would come to this House and would simply be passed by this House without any questions being asked. That is a more responsible approach to this issue.
There are two other areas I would like to spend a little more time on. One is with respect to small business. This bill purports to make changes to the Small Businesses Loans Act which will increase the amount of loans that are available under this act from $100,000 to $200,000. It is important to point out some of the background with respect to this bill.
Since its establishment in 1961, the objective of the Small Businesses Loans Act has been to encourage private commercial lenders to make term loans to small business enterprises for financing the establishment, expansion, modernization and improvement of specified fixed assets, equipment, premises and land. The rate of interest must not exceed chartered bank rates of prime plus one. That is all very well. As well, the federal government is liable to pay 85 per cent of any loss sustained by a lender as a result of a loan made under this act since 1985.

November 30, 1992
Government Orders
There is nothing wrong with that aspect of the act. There is nothing wrong with increasing the amount available under the act for loans. However, there are problems with this bill, the main one being that small businesses are having difficulty getting any loans under this act. In fact, trying to obtain a loan in the first place is a major task. One main reason is that the attitude of the banks is that most small business people are simply a bad risk. I have been told by people in my riding that if a small business entrepreneur has an opportunity and is a good credit risk, banks often time will not even mention the Small Businesses Loans Act and will offer them money under a different program. Of course, the goal of banks is to bring in the most revenue possible. As we have seen in recent days, bank revenues are at record highs for a number of the chartered banks.
It is interesting to note that the number of small business improvement loans made by lenders has decreased from almost 35,000 in 1985 to a little over 10,000 in 1991. That is a major decrease. The amount of money lent decreased from over $1 billion in 1985 to something like $413 million in 1991.
We have to emphasize that the banks have a responsibility to help end the recession. The problem with the Small Businesses Loans Act is that we need the banks to make it work. Small businesses create over 80 per cent of the new jobs in Canada, but the banks would apparently rather lend to large businesses than to small business entrepreneurs. Therefore, increasing the limit to $200,000 is simply not going to help the small business operator if he is trying to get a loan for $40,000 or $50,000. It does not help them.
Small businesses are hurting. Business bankruptcies are up again. In September over 1,200 businesses failed, up 18 per cent. While the banks are cutting back on loans under $100,000 to small businesses under the Small Businesses Loans Act, in the fiscal year ending March 31, more than 85 per cent of all funds for loans and guarantees by the Federal Business Development Bank were in the over $100,000 category. This government needs to provide more risk and venture capital for small businesses and simply not just to larger firms.
I think we on this side of the House would all agree that small business plays an integral, essential role in the economy of this country. Over the last several years the small business sector has been responsible for most of
the new job opportunities. Between 1980 and 1989, Stats Canada indicates that almost 80 per cent of the new jobs created in this country were created by small businesses with less than 50 employees.
Small businesses are often the mainstay of many small rural communities. I know that from experience in Saskatchewan, having been part of a major rural paper for this party. In fact, it is the first federal party to have a rural policy. I travelled to many parts of rural Canada this last year.
Small businesses are a mainstay in rural communities. This government and other governments have not focused attention on the need to help small businesses in rural communities. Certainly, this measure is not going to help them either.
Full employment can only be achieved with the full co-operation of Canada's small business sector. There is an unfair tax burden in that small businesses still pay an average tax rate higher than Canada's largest businesses. The GST will add further hardships both in compliance costs and in accounting costs for the small business person.
Ninety-eight per cent of small businesses are Canadian owned. Their earnings are usually reinvested right back into the community and into the Canadian economy.
Small businesses operate under severe constraints in the Canadian economy which in turn limits their potential to produce even more jobs. Constraints, such as high costs for development capital, severe undercapitalization, high interest rates and higher taxation levels compared to corporations put small business at a real disadvantage in the Canadian economy.
What should we do about this? The federal New Democratic Party has suggested a number of alternatives including: ensuring that banks provide more loans to small businesses at the rates given to big corporations; establishing a more aggressive buy Canada program which includes government contracts and is targeted to the small business and community enterprises; providing risk and venture capital for small businesses; providing greater opportunities for women to establish small businesses including the commitment by the banks to treat women in an equal manner; and identifying areas in which small business could expand to meet consumer demand now covered by imports.
November 30, 1992

We should be providing small businesses with relevant financial marketing and management assistance through federal one-stop shopping centres to be organized in conjunction with local business communities. This is really important in rural Canada. Reform of the Federal Business Development Bank is needed to focus its activities on small business, especially those most in need.
Canadian Patents and Development Ltd. should be directed to work with small businesses to help them patent new innovations and to market those patents world-wide.
The tax system should be changed to make severance pay tax exempt and to allow the tax-free use of RRSPs to start up new small businesses. We must immediately move away from the high interest rate policy that this government has pursued and as well withdraw the GST.
Those are measures that the New Democratic Party has suggested. They are measures which would help small businesses.
Although the increase in the funding from $100,000 to $200,000 in terms of loans in the Small Businesses Loans Act is fine, it certainly is not enough. It is certainly not going to help small businesses that are struggling today or many individuals who are thinking of starting up small businesses.
We all know that small business people spend a lot of hours working at their small businesses. Many of these people do not spend 35 or 40 hours a week working in their businesses; they will spend 75 to 80 hours or more. Often that person is the manager, the accountant and the clerk. You name it, they do it all. Those people have not received the respect they deserve from this Parliament.
Those are some of the measures my party and I support. They are measures which are essential if small business is really going to survive in this country.
I would also like to make some comments with respect to the fourth area with which this bill deals. That is with respect to student loans. This government is planning to
Government Orders
remove the six month interest-free provision that is presently in place for student loans.
I remember when I was a student. I studied education initially and I also studied law. I graduated in April and was fortunate to get a job. In those days, there was still a big need for teachers and my job started in September. I had all of May, June, July, August, September and October before I had to pay interest on my loan.
That was very important for me because at that point, having been a student for some four or five years, I had a lot of debts. I had over $10,000 in student loans to pay back. It was essential for me to allow myself to get established. I taught in a small town in Kipling, Saskatchewan. I moved to that town. I moved my family there and incurred debts moving to that community.
The interest-free provision was very much appreciated by me. There are lots of students today who, even if they do get a job after completing school, should have the opportunity to establish themselves in the work place. This is simply not going to happen now.
To be faced with an interest burden as soon as students graduate simply is not fair. Many students find themselves out of luck and do not get jobs with anywhere from $8,000 to $18,000 in loans. If they still do not have a job after a year or so, their best course is to declare bankruptcy. That is what I would advise them to do.
Why should they be faced with that burden? They come out of school owing $18,000 or $20,000 and that is rising at the rate of who knows what the interest rates might be because they seem to be going up and down like a yo-yo. The last thing they need if they start working after a year or so is to face that increasing burden. This government is simply encouraging people to avoid paying those bills.
The hon. member for Sault Ste. Marie also raised a very important point with respect to the fact that students are often hassled with their loans. I have had constituents come into my office as well. A number of times former students have come in and have said that they are working at a minimum wage job somewhere, or

November 30, 1992

that they do not have a job yet, or that they are single parents. There is a whole host of situations.
In any case, they are being hassled by collection agencies. I have had occasions to deal with a few of those agencies on the phone and it is very difficult. It is not very pleasant nor very fair to have a collection agency harassing a student. This government should do something about that. If it wanted to help students, it could start with this.
The 3 per cent surtax now on student loans which the government said it was going to remove but is still being taken off the top when a student gets a loan is also a burden. Yes, it is a lot of money when you are a student and you do not have a lot of money to spend. You lose 3 per cent off the top of a loan that you have to pay back and that you are going to pay interest on as soon as you graduate.
It is true. As I listened to debate on this bill today there were some comments with respect to the fact that moneys given to the provinces for education are not always channelled to that particular goal or objective. The accountability is not there. This was something that was removed by the Liberals back in 1975 and has not been dealt with since. One of the ways the government could deal more efficiently and effectively with student loans would be to put that accountability in place. That would be helpful.
As far as students repaying the loans not only should we be providing a six-month grace period, we should also be providing a grace period until the student obtains a job. Then the government would get its money back. We would not have the $600 million or $700 million in outstanding loans that are not being paid back to the government. Students would be making payments on their loans. When a student has a mounting debt and is trying to make payments on the loan but is having a very difficult time just meeting the interest payments it does not make him or her very anxious to pay that debt off.
We should show a little more respect for our students. After all, if we are going to compete in this world and if we are going to be a competitive nation, we are going to need educated Canadians.
We want to encourage people to go to school. We do not want people to be detracted from going to school because of lack of finances. We want to be encouraging
people to take out loans to get an education and contribute to society. When a student graduates and there is no job available, it is not that student's fault. What we should be doing, I would suggest, is providing an interest-free period until that student obtains a job.
Although there are derelicts in this country who will negate their obligations, the vast majority of students do not fall into that category at all. In fact, I would suggest that the vast majority of students would be more than willing and would want to pay back their loans.
Students should be treated fairly. Once they have a job and start making a contribution to this country they can pay back their loans and can start paying interest. However, to burden students with a debt load before they find a job is unfair.
What this government is doing with the proposed changes to the student loan legislation is not going to help the government or the students and that is unfortunate. Therefore, I certainly will not be supporting this portion of that legislation and I believe the rest of my colleagues in this party will not be supporting it either.

Mr. Speaker, with respect to the question by my hon. colleague across the way, it is certainly very tempting with the GST and its some $18 billion or thereabouts which I believe it brings in every year to maintain that sort of tax. It is not a progressive tax; it is a regressive tax. The hon. member says it is a progressive tax but it is a regressive tax. We on this side of the House are opposed to regressive taxes.
This country survived for 125 years without a GST and it has only been in the last little while that we have had a GST. There are alternatives. What is needed in this country is some true, progressive tax legislation. This government should do a complete revision of the Income Tax Act. The Income Tax Act is not designed solely for getting tax revenue from Canadians. It is an act that has all sorts of social programs, social initiatives and economic initiatives tied to it. The Income Tax Act is cumbersome. Corporations hire accountants, tax lawyers and others and pay them good salaries, $80,000, $100,000 or $120,000 a year to find loopholes in it.
The previous Minister of Finance said he was going to simplify the Income Tax Act. All he has done is complicate it. The first thing we should do is take the Income Tax Act and throw it out and come back with a truly

Mr. Speaker, I thought I was going to get a break today and get the NDP to endorse a single tax. I guess no such luck. I keep hoping.
I want to begin my remarks today by referring to that portion of the bill that deals with the Small Businesses Loans Act. I have stood in this House several times and have said that I believe this is good legislation, the fact that we are taking the Small Businesses Loans Act from $100,000 and doubling it to $200,000.
Most Canadians do not realize that essentially this means that if I ran a small business and I went to my local bank, and provided the bank manager knew about the program, I could be entitled to up to $200,000 in a loan from that bank on capital items. The bank is supposed to be progressive in its attitude of lending under this legislation because the bank is guaranteed 85 per cent of the loan if the company should go into default.
My problem with this legislation is the fact that very few bankers across Canada know about this program. I have been pleading for months with this government to try to do something to communicate to all the bank managers in Canada that this legislation exists.
If the government were to do this, it would go a long way in rekindling some spirit of hope and confidence in the small business sector. I will not go into a long dissertation on the importance of small business to the economy of this country because we all know that small business employs close to 80 per cent of the people.
We also know that the greatest hope for new job creation lies in this particular sector. The government needs to address the communications aspect of this particular part of the legislation, the Small Businesses Loans Act.
The second thing I find frustrating is that it has taken us almost a year to put this amendment to the Small Businesses Loans Act through the House of Commons. This is the kind of thing I really believe serves us poorly as legislators, as members of Parliament.
It is almost nine months since the Minister of Finance announced this legislation. The press reports would talk about the Small Businesses Loans Act going from $100,000 to $200,000. That creates an expectation with many businessmen out there that there is something in this budget for them. It is almost a year later and we still have not made this legislation come alive with the business community of this country.
Basically there is all-party agreement on this legislation. It seems to me that when we think about little things we could do that are not going to cost the treasury any money, things we could do to stimulate the economy, deal in some hope with the small business sector, here is legislation that could have gone through this House six months ago and there would not have been anyone on
November 30, 1992

this side to say that we are against moving this legislation through too quickly.
As someone who comes from a small and mediumsized business background, I can tell you if there is one thing that tends to discourage an entrepreneur, not from time to time but often about the way this place works, is that we seem to take so long doing so many simple things, and this is a specific example.
The other thing I would like to deal with is that section of the bill which deals with the amendments to the Lobbyists Registration Act. The amendment gives the Governor in Council regulation-making power to enact regulations charging a fee to be paid by lobbyists when as required by the act they register under the act.
I am going to be critical of the government on this particular part of the legislation. The Lobbyists Registration Act is like smoke and mirrors. Basically we are amending the act so that from now on lobbyists are going to be charged when they register.
We need a full debate on how the lobbyists or the government relations people who are involved in that exercise in this city interact with members of Parliament, interact with officials, interact with the entire policymaking apparatus.
I watched the member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore last night on cable 10 in Toronto where he was being interviewed on, I think, John Tory's show. The subject being discussed was the way lobbyists were basically manipulating the system from the bottom up in this town. I commend the hon. member for his straightforward remarks. They were right on the button as far as I am concerned.
I can remember back in 1980 there were a few lobbyists around this town but they tended to be people who would try and advocate a thrust that was more along the lines of policy-making or policy amendments.
In the last five or six years I have noticed the incredible industry of lobbyists that has emerged. It is like a whole new sector of the Ottawa economy. These various government relations vice-presidents and various associations not only work on policy but are now lobbying for
Government Orders
grants and are lobbying for contracts for privatization of airport terminals. It is the most incredible thing.
It is at a point now where anything of substance that goes on in this city by-passes most MPs. Good lobbyists will deal with a cabinet minister's office. Let us say it is something to do with transport. They will deal with senior officials and with critics directly related to that particular issue. They will basically by-pass the whole parliamentary process.
We do not need some little tinkering amendment to the act which is contained in this particular bill. We need a full-blown debate on what goes on in this city and in this country with the lobbyists.
It is not that I am against the exercise of people wanting to advance their particular point of view, whether it be the auto sector, the oil sector or whatever. What bothers me about it is the way the whole thing is shrouded in secrecy.
In the United States all lobbyists are registered, but they also have to report their sales and their fees. In other words, if I was a lobbyist representing a particular client in the oil industry or the oil sector I have to register the amount of money that I received from that particular account.
If all of a sudden it is seen that I am representing a particular industry and at the end of the month or at the end of a six-month period I post that I received $10 million in fees from a particular sector of the economy people will certainly know where my thrust is coming from. It tends to make people a little more alert to what is going on in the process.
It is incumbent upon the government as it is preparing itself to do a little bit of a face-lift over the next 30 days-we understand that the government is preparing a Speech from the Throne and maybe right at the top of the list it could say that it is going to take a good hard look and review the lobby system, how it works and how it affects the parliamentary process in this country.
Maybe before this particular Parliament ends some of us can become relevant again. Right now, as most of us would agree, it seems that on any given day the lobbyists are more relevant than some of us.

The member for Broadview-Greenwood spoke of the minimal contact between these representatives of special interests in our society and those of us who are elected officials. Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak on Bill C-76, an act to amend certain statutes to implement certain fiscal provisions of the budget tabled in Parliament on February 25, 1992.
There are four parts to this bill: changes to the Canada Student Loans Program, to the Lobbyists Registration Act, the Salaries Act, and the Small Businesses Loans Act. I wish to speak mainly to the Student Loans Act portions of the bill and to the small business provisions of the bill.
In the riding of Kootenay East we are about 1,400 kilometres from the closest university. When students make applications for their loans we know the kinds of problems they are facing when they come from that distance and the kinds of costs that are involved. To see what the government is doing I say is nothing worse than shameful. It is a tragedy.
It is a tragedy that this government comes out with these kinds of drastic changes to the Canada Student Loans Program during a time when it stands in this House and talks about competitiveness, about how we must retrain people and about how people must be better educated to be able to be competitive in the job markets that are going to be.
To say that a student, after he has completed his program, is not going to be entitled to the six-month
grace period for interest on the loan when he pays it back at the end is nothing other than thievery. When these students come out most of them have spent their lives putting together and borrowing money to be able to go through university. They need a good six months to be able to re-establish themselves. They need the time to be able to adjust and find the locations where they are going to live and set up their lifestyle so that they can start to pay back their loans.
However, the government is saying no. It is saying that it is going to do away with the six months of grace. Immediately upon coming out of university they must pay them back. It is shameful. The government is talking about competitiveness and retraining. There are 1.5 million unemployed people at the present time, yet the government brings about these kinds of changes under the Canada Student Loans Program. At its semi-annual general meeting in May 1992 the Canadian Federation of Students adopted its policy. The federation is opposed to the government's abandonment of the original objective of the Canada Student Loans Program of enhanced access to post-secondary education. Again this is an attack on the students.
They oppose a statement for the Canada Student Loans Program based on speedy completion of the program. They oppose the establishment of a special operating agency to administer the Canada Student Loans Program. They oppose the elimination of interest subsidies on student loans for a six month cessation of studies, which I have already indicated. They oppose the government's move to divest itself of the public responsibility for providing 100 per cent guarantee of Canada student loans. They oppose the federal government's risk sharing arrangement with financial institutions as a means to guarantee Canada student loans.
They oppose the application of the commercial interest rate on Canada student loans. They oppose the increase from 60 per cent of full course load to 80 per cent in order to be eligible for a Canada student loan. They oppose the reduction of the limit of total borrowing from 520 weeks to 340 weeks under the Canada Student Loans Program. They oppose the government's move to end forgiveness provisions for students with disabilities under the Canada Student Loans Program. This is
November 30, 1992

shameful. No wonder not many government members are speaking on this legislation. It is very hard to defend.

If this bill addressed that problem and set up a system whereby small businesses were treated with some compassion, with some sensitivity and some recognition of what is required by the banks, we would find that they would be in a much better operating state than they are under this piece of legislation.
Is it any wonder that many small businesses have gone bankrupt. Foreclosures have taken place. Loans are not available for inventory financing, working capital requirements or the refinancing of existing debts, but it can finance up to 90 per cent of the eligible cost of land and premises and up to 80 per cent of the cost of equipment. The rate of interest must not exceed chartered bank rates prime plus 1 per cent.

A small business enterprise is one operating for profit with an estimated gross revenue which does not exceed $2 million in the year of application for whose principal business is in communications, construction, fish, manufacturing retail trade, service businesses, transportation or wholesale trade.
The federal government is liable to pay up to 85 per cent of any loss sustained by a lender as a result of the loan made after March 31, 1985.
This piece of legislation is not going to address the problems of these small business people, the ones requiring anywhere from $20,000 to $50,000 to be able to bring about the kind of help needed to cariy them through or possibly even for their inventory. Those provisions are not there.
As might be expected from the above, the main problem for small businesses is not the loan limits. It is trying to obtain the loan in the first place. The attitude of the banks is that most small businesses are bad credit risks. That has to be changed. Increasing the limit is fine. We are not against that, but the banks have to be more co-operative. There is no sense increasing the limits if the banks will not lend the money in the first place.
Over the last several years the small business sector has been responsible for most new job opportunities. Between 1980 and 1987, Statistics Canada data indicates that almost 80 per cent of new jobs created in Canada were created by small businesses with less than 50 employees. This was true even during the recession in the 1980s when many larger corporations were laying workers off.
Small business is often the mainstay of many smaller rural communities. That is certainly the situation in my area.
They are feeling the pinch now and they need help. They need it now. Full employment can only be achieved with the full co-operation of Canada's small business sector. With regard to unfair tax burdens, small business still pays an average tax rate that is higher than Canada's largest businesses.
The GST will add further hardships both in compliance costs and in accounting costs for the small
business person. Ninety-eight per cent of Canadian businesses are Canadian-owned. Their earnings are usually reinvested into the community and the Canadian economy.
Small businesses operate under severe constraints in the Canadian economy which in turn limits their potential to stimulate the economy and produce more jobs. There are constraints such as high costs for development capital, severe undercapitalization, high interest rates and higher taxation levels than corporations. This puts small businesses at a real disadvantage in the Canadian economy.
That is the problem. Large amounts of money are available. The banks are only interested in loaning out the large loans. They are not interested in the small businessman who comes in with his little problems. They figure there is too big a risk. They have not got the time to spend with them so they let them go.
It is a tragedy that during this period when we are talking about competitiveness and governments are talking about saving money and cutting back, it is cutting back on the two areas that could create the best benefits for the government.
Student loans provide students with the capacity to come out fully trained to be able to meet the demands of our future. Small businesses need help now to be able to hire people and get the economy going. The government is doing neither.
In closing, I appeal to the government to rethink this piece of legislation, to reintroduce it with more compassion, with more desire to bring about the kind of training and education system that we all want in Canada where our students can afford to go to university, get the training they want so that when they come out they will be of benefit to our country and our people.
Our small business people should be able to go to the bank with dignity. They should be able to walk into the bank with some confidence that they will be given a fair and equitable hearing. They should have an opportunity to be able to either pick up some inventory money to assist them with their inventory or to carry them through some difficult times or to be able to get some money to be able to offset some adverse circumstances that have occurred in the economy.

Further, they should be able to reinvest or redo their mortgage and carry it over a longer period of time so that they can sustain themselves through these difficult economic times. If the government were to take that approach, this would be a much better piece of legislation. It would be legislation that we on this side could support. We certainly cannot support this legislation.
It is unfortunate that there are four pieces tied into this legislation because there are parts with which I can agree. I agree with cabinet ministers taking a reduction in pay during this period of time, as set out in the bill. I can agree to some of the lobbyist statements in the bill. However I have to say to my constituents that students in my riding and students across Canada are going to find it very difficult to be able to get the amount of money that is required for them to carry on with their university studies.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am going to start my remarks by saying how profoundly I disagree with what I have just heard. It might sound to some people that it is a trivial matter to be charging a fee to lobbyists. I submit that it is not.
I have before me Erskine May Parliamentary Practice, twentieth edition. I want to read about the fundamental right of anyone to be able to speak to a member of this House without having to pay a fee. That is fundamental to a democracy.
Let me read some of it:
The right of petitioning the Crown -
That means the right to make representation to any one of us.
-for redress of grievances is acknowledged as a fundamental principle of the constitution. It has been uninterruptedly exercised from the very early times, and has had profound effect in determining the main forms of parliamentary procedure.
I read further:
The rights of petitioners and the power of the House to deal with petitions were expressed in two resolutions of the Commons in 1669.
For 323 years people have been able to address Parliament without paying a fee. There is no reason why a lobbyist should be called upon to pay a fee today.
Sure, there are a few lobbyists that could make it into the list of the top 500 people in Canada. Sure, there are a few of them. That does not apply though to the Canadian Federation of Agriculture, the Red Cross, labour unions or a small business in my riding or the riding of the hon. member who wants to have a meeting with any one of us to come and ask for a grant, to come and ask us for help.

November 30, 1992
Government Orders
Why should people have to pay to see an MP? That is wrong. I do not care what anyone says. That is wrong. No one should ever have to pay to see a parliamentarian.
The law we have now for lobbyists, Bill C-82, received royal assent on September 13, 1988 and came into force September 30, 1989, a year later. Let me tell what parliamentarians had to say at that time. This was a unanimous report of our committee. I ask the hon. member from the NDP to listen to what his own colleagues had to say in a report that we tabled in this House. On January 27, 1987 page 2-15 our committee said: that there would be no cost associated with the filing of information and lobbying matters.
On June 30, 1987 the Ministry of Consumer and Corporate Affairs outlined what it proposed to do. Here is what it said: "There will be no charge to lobbyists to register and there will only be nominal cost to cover the cost of photocopying and such for people seeking information from the system". That is what it said.
Let me tell you what the then Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and now government House leader said on June 30, 1987. He said, speaking to the Lobbyist Registration Act: "It addresses fairly and reasonably and effectively the public's need to know who is intervening and why". Listen to this: "It does so without placing any restrictions or burdens on the rights of Canadians to talk to their members of Parliament, or deal with the government on issues affecting them directly".
That is what the minister at that time said. It is an important issue. It is not just that we found a device here to get a few dollars out of someone that is rich. Even if they were all rich, which they are not, it would be wrong. They are not all rich.
Let me tell you what some of the groups have had to say about this measure. I read here a text that actually appeared in our parliamentary newspaper, The Hill Times. Sean Moore, a person who is quite familiar with the lobbyist registration system and has written more about it than probably anyone else save and except the hon. member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore perhaps, said: "In order to recover the costs the fee every time would have to be $54 per transaction". That is including
registration and deregistration. Assuming you will not charge anyone to deregister, the cost would have to be $75 dollars per transaction. Can you imagine the Federation of Agriculture of my riding having to spend $75 for the privilege of talking to the hon. member sitting over there? Is that right to him? It is not to me.
Certainly the government can make a case for cost recovery on any other section of the bill. I would vote against it anyway because I will not agree, but on that section there is not just a principle of cost recovery. There is another principle far more important. It affects our rights as parliamentarians in this House and, more important, the rights of each and every Canadian to have the opportunity to address any one of us without having to pay a registration fee. That is the important principle, I submit.
I see my hon. colleague across from Etobicoke-Lake-shore. He is very knowledgeable in this area. He has worked on this in the past, has produced papers, has written about it and knows the issue very well. I worked on the committee that established our present lobbyist registration rules. I did so with the hon. member for Nickel Belt, the hon. member for Peace River and several others in this House. We produced legislation which is not bad.
It needs to be updated now because some people have found loopholes in it. As a matter of fact, as we are today debating this particular bill containing that clause, this same House has appointed another committee to review the lobbyist registration system. That is how wrong all of this is. It is absurd what we are doing right now.
Regarding the consumer and corporate affairs committee to which has been referred the Lobbyists Registration Act pursuant to the adoption of some years ago, we had a steering committee meeting the other day at which I recommended to Our chairman, the member for Portage-Interlake, that both the member for Etobicoke- Lakeshore and the member for Peace River be seconded to that committee because of their expertise so that we can all work together to improve the bill, to get rid of what I euphemistically call the MacAdam loophole or other loopholes that exist in the legislation and find ways of making it better.
November 30, 1992

I want to do that but I say to members of cabinet that if that is what they want, why do they not submit that proposal to our parliamentary committee, have it reviewed by all members of this House, test it out and listen to witnesses on it, not move it unilaterally and in the disguise of a cost recovery bill because that is wrong? That affects all of our privileges as MPs, both in this House and in the other place.
If no one from the government side-I do not mean from the benches other than the cabinet, but at least from the cabinet rows-listens to this today in this House, I hope that members from the other place will take this issue most seriously because it affects them individually and collectively as it affects us as members individually and collectively.
I say to all hon. members of this House read that clause in the legislation. Read it carefully. Read what others have said about it. I think you will agree as I do that this clause is not only bad in terms of cost recovery-you can argue, agree, or disagree on that point- but it is bad because it infringes upon our privileges as parliamentarians and upon the rights of those we are called upon to represent.
That is why we should not even be voting on that particular clause. It should be removed from the bill altogether and if the government wants to proceed with that approach-even though I happen to think it is wrong-it can make that submission to the committee looking at the bill and can argue it there. Witnesses can make representation. The anti-poverty group can come and say whether it thinks it is right or wrong to have a fee for lobbyists.
Big business can come and make the same pitch if that is what it likes, but that is the forum in which to do it, not this bill because that is not right.
If members were to listen to this testimony, not just mine, but that made by others who are experts in the field, they would know that this is not a good idea.
The only salvation I can think of at this time is that this particular clause is discretionary. It says the Governor in Council may make regulation.
My only hope today is if this government is so wrong-headed as to proceed with that particular clause, at the very least it will either not promulgate it or not file any regulations afterward, not gazette any regulations
Government Orders
pursuant to that clause so that at least we will not be subjected to the clause in question before we have that rigorous test that we are going to have as an institution when we review the Lobbyists Registration Act in the time to come.
I know I have been given up to 20 minutes to comment on this but I feel so profoundly about this particular clause that I shall not address any other part of the bill. I will limit my comments to this and instead invite colleagues to question me on this. I feel it is an important principle, one that each of us should think about today. Hopefully the government will think about this again. If it does not choose to withdraw the offensive section in question, at the very least the next best thing will be never to promulgate it and next best to that is to never produce regulations prior to the testing of this whole idea by the parliamentary committee in question.
