speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to respond to some of the points our colleague has raised.
First of all, I do not question that it is the role of the Department of Finance to produce legislation to raise funds. That is the role of the minister, too. It is our role as parliamentarians to sort through that. That is where I think-and I am not anticipating a vote of the House here-we will probably fail later today.
In my own mind I am trying to think that if this kind of bill were presented before the British House of Commons there would likely be a backbench revolt. What are we doing about it? Not much. In a few minutes we will be voting on this bill and the sad reality is that because it is included with other measures which will be largely
supported by government members, which is understandable, this will likely carry with it as well. That is what is wrong. That is what is so terrible about this.
The failure is not one of the Department of Finance. Collectively and individually it will be ours as an institution in a very few minutes. That provision should be put in abeyance and it would certainly be a very worthwhile suggestion that the first motion passed by the committee be one to ask the government not to implement this change before a thorough airing before the committee reviewing the lobbyist legislation.
The committee will no doubt want to review this possibility of charging fees. It will want to review whether the fees of lobbyists should be made public or whether the disbursements to lobbyists should be made public. That is the case in California. It is a good idea to review that and discuss the merits for and against, what amount and so on, thresholds and what have you, and decide whether paid and unpaid lobbyists or paid lobbyists doing unpaid activities should be registered. That is a loophole that exists now.
All of this is not because lobbying is sinister, evil or wrong. There is nothing wrong with doing that. At least I submit there is nothing wrong. Every time a constituent phones any one of us asking for his rights, defending his rights, airing his grievances, that is lobbying. That is okay. Whether someone charges or does it for free it does not make any difference providing it is done legally and with all good intent and with the opposing party's right to know, being there. We have the lobbyist registration system so that the opposing side can be heard. The opposing side can know who is doing what to whom. That is proper. There is nothing wrong with that.
However, our role has to ensure that we have a strong system to preserve integrity; a system that will ensure that everyone can know what is happening in the best possible way and at the same time no one is hindered in his or her attempts to reach Parliament or, to put it in ancient terms, to petition Parliament, being any one of us individually or all of us collectively.
In conclusion, that is why I feel so strongly about this clause. I submit to all my colleagues that they should take a few moments to reflect upon it as well.

subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wanted to participate in this debate this afternoon because I think it marks a trend I see not just here in this House of Commons but across Canada and it disturbs me.
It is fair game for governments at all levels to turn to their senior staff and talk about revenue; how to generate more revenue for government, how it could be done in a creative way. I am disturbed by the outcome of the process, much like the previous member said in some of his remarks.
If the Parliament of Canada were given a long list of ways in which more money could be generated, that would seem to me to be a fair, open, reasonable and sensible process and we could somehow pass judgment on what is a good idea and what is a bad idea.
The process that I work with here and have worked with in other places does not really ever do that. This bill in its current form strikes me as being the most wrongheaded approach you could conceivably come up with; four rather disjointed notions about how to raise revenue all put together in one bill. Somehow it then gets translated into something that would be almost a matter of confidence. It is impossible to tear the four pieces apart and say that this might be supportable but this is not, or to examine the good and the bad of each one of the four sections of the bill, or to say that somehow this would be a sensible way for a government to raise revenue. It has all kind of bonded together in one bill. Therefore I think there is an error in process in that sense.
There is also something about this that whenever governments decide to squeeze the system it somehow always grabs the wrong person and squeezes that person. In this bill, for example, students are being asked to kind of give up a bit of an advantage in that they had a grace period, only six months and only for those who received Canada student loans. We are not talking about a lot of people, but surely of all those people in our society whom a government could raise a little more money from this is not the group to hit on.
This is not the only government in Canada to target this group. Whether it means to do that, whether there is a great deal of thought in going through it or whether this somehow just kind of pops up on a computer somewhere and makes it through an internal, quiet,
Government Orders
secretive selection process that says get more money from this group, I cannot believe that a group of members of this Parliament would sit down in open debate anyway and say: "Here is a group you ought to get more money from, students. Let us nail them before they even have a job. Let us nail handicapped students in particular. They are unlikely to ever get a job so get at them right away". That does not seem to me to be a logical outcome of a process.
In my own province, for example, a young woman was in to see me about an ID card that she had received from the province of Ontario. Between the time she had sought the application for the card and actually filled it out the price of that identification had risen from $3 to $15. I know Ontario is in hard times and I know the government in Ontario is looking for all kinds of ways to generate revenue, but was that the outcome of a thoughtful process, that this is where you need to generate your income?
In this bill here, is this the outcome of a thoughtful process? I think not.
As the previous member went through the Lobbyists Registration Act portion on this, I would not mind touching on that a bit as well. I do not read anywhere in here that somebody who wants to come and talk to me is now going to be charged a fee. Nobody I know would be stupid enough to pay such a fee in the first place and there is nothing in this bill that I read that says they have to do that, but there is certainly a lot of open-endedness here. The actual fees may well be set by a government sometime at a later day and, if it thinks of it, it may even tell the Parliament of Canada what it has done. That is surely the wrong way to do that.
If there is a problem with lobbyists, and I would be one who would advocate that there is and who would advocate that you ought to have some kind of a registration act that worked, the current situation seems to kind of blow it all away. At the same time that the government is changing this act, another parliamentary committee is going to review it once again. That cannot be a logical process either.
If the general public is somehow saying it has given up on politics, perhaps this is one of the reasons why. Perhaps this is one of the things that makes people in their living rooms ask what is going on here; the government is passing an act and reviewing an act at the same. Different acts are being reviewed in different ways. Somehow to those of us who play the parliamenta-

November 30, 1992
Government Orders
ry sport it makes some sense if you turn your mind to it. However, to the general public it makes no sense.
There are changes in here about loans to small businesses as well. I found it interesting as I read through that section of the act that deals with small business loans, but that is not the problem that most small businesses talk to me about. They do not have a problem with limits, they have a problem with getting somebody to loan them money. If we were trying to turn this economy over one would think that whether the government in particular wants to directly provide loan moneys to small businesses, which would be one mechanism it could use, or even if it just wanted to help small businesses secure loans from private lending institutions which would be another way to do, that at least is identifying the problem and doing something about it.
The confusion in the public mind exists concerning the question of why raise the limits when nobody is going to get a loan anyway? That seems to be the problem. I can think of two or three federal agencies all purporting to help small business. I go to meetings and get briefing notes from all these agencies whose purpose in life is to assist somebody with a small business. I would have to tell members that I have never seen one of them actually help somebody. I am sure they do. I have just never seen it happen, but I have been in politics for only 20 years. Maybe in my 21st year in public life it will happen, but I have not seen it take place yet.
I know they have seminars on how to do this. I know they put out very attractive brochures on how to do this. I know they are very active at every reception I have ever been to, but I have never seen them perform what is purportedly their basic function: helping somebody get a loan.
I find it pretty difficult to defend when I see somebody who is supposedly out there assisting small business. People come in my office and say: "I have a small business. I would like to employ five more people. I have five in my work place now. I would like to employ five more and I cannot find anybody who will help me".
I will say: here is an agency of the federal government or an agency of the provincial government or an agency at the municipal level and they are all supposedly helping small business get started. Inevitably they all come back to me and say: "They seem to want to lend money to people who do not need it. They seem to want to help those who are already a success. They seem to want to buy into a winning idea, but nobody really wants to help a small business group that is just starting out".
I talked to a guy this morning who has just exactly that problem. He has some good ideas. He has some good products. He would like to employ more people, but there are no agencies in place to help him. Two years from now, if he makes a success of his business, there will be all kinds of people wanting to buy into that idea. That is the tragedy of this bill and many other bills of the same ilk that seem somehow to identify a problem and then get totally irrelevant when it comes to providing solutions. That is what I find ironic about this entire process.
This process, this bill in particular, does not make any sense to me. Somebody could say: "Why do you not take one of your parliamentary committees, some senior staff, and identify all the ways in which governments can generate more money? Let the parliamentary committee report annually, never mind once in its lifetime, on things that are stupid, on ways in which governments could either reduce their expenditures or raise some more money".
That would be a fair and open process that all of us could watch happen. We could understand the logic or the lack of logic that is the outcome of that, and we would at least know what is going on. This bill, it seems to me, is one of those classic examples of somebody turning to senior staff and saying: "Find me some more money somewhere in the system". The four solutions that are presented here do not do anybody any real good.
There is even a section in here that talks about the cabinet's salary. I am sure that is wonderful, but I am also sure that will not feed one family in Canada this year. That is a shame because there was an opportunity through this type of activity to rationalize governments. That perhaps is a contradiction in terms, but it seems to me that governments do not have to be this illogical, this irrational.
November 30, 1992

There are ways and means in which members of this House could serve a useful purpose, could identify areas where governments are spending money that they do not need to spend. They could probably even identify some ways somewhat like these that could generate a few more funds and would not really hurt people.
It seems to me that at the nub of this bill the wrong thing is being done. It is attacking the wrong people and doing something that really will not help anybody. It seems to me that is wrong.
